Up front disclaimer: having owned many android, apple and windows devices (from all the big manufacturers), I am partial to none. I think they all have pros and cons.

I was excited when I saw this tablet was coming out, with a quad core processor, a better display than its Tab 3 predecessor, and of course Android 4.4. It looked like a much better version of an affordable tablet.

It's ok. It's not bad, and I wouldn't rate it as such. But I did a physical comparison between it and the 2013 Nexus 7, which in my opinion is a valuable comparison since they are both on the same version of Android, and are both lower priced 7 inch tablets. The Galaxy Tab 4 7.0 doesn't even come close. This is for one big reason - lag. My guess is that this has everything to do with Samsung's custom Android skin, TouchWiz. There is noticeable lag when using the browser and other apps. There is noticeable lag when switching applications. Not all the time, but enough to make it a nuisance. This was not the case on the Nexus, which was snappy and smooth in all my use of it.

Other points of comparison - the screen is not nearly as vivid on the Tab 4 as it is on the Nexus. The camera seemed slightly better on the Nexus, but really, it's a tablet... I'm not concerned with that so much. I do like the physical home button on the Galaxy but do not miss it having made the switch to the Nexus 7.

All in all, for the specs on the Galaxy Tab 4, it should really perform with no lag. It's disappointing to say the least. It is definitely not a "bad" tablet, and if you just want to spend 200 and no more, then you'll probably get the most out of it. But for not a lot more, you can get a much better experience in my humble opinion by getting the latest Nexus tab.

This Tab 4 WiFi tablet is just what I was searching for in the 7.0 model. I have used and tested thoroughly and found that it does have so many overall advantages. Now as a techie, I tested this tablet out to great lengths and below I will list what I have found to be the Pros and Cons of this amazing device.  (I purchased mine NEW, it was worth it new rather than Refurbished or Used, for the money, I believe worth the small amount extra).
If you are looking for: a lightweight tablet that is very easy to hold in one hand comfortably and you want a basic and easy to use tablet, then consider this tablet. While it does not have every bell and whistle installed on it, it is a good choice for: Checking emails, Getting Online, Looking at Pictures, Watching Home Movies. Here are the Pros and the Cons below:

PROS:

1- WiFi connects easily and the signal is good in most places I tested. And I received a STRONG WiFi signal on this device. In fact I have a very, very strong WiFi signal even in the back of my home (furthest from my router).
Here is a tip: If you ever have trouble with your WiFi Router, unplug it for 2 minutes and then plug in again. In about 2 minutes, it will reset itself and should work wonderfully.

2- The advantage of having a SD card slot that will hold up to 64GB.

3- Small and lightweight. Comfortable to carry around and place in backpack or briefcase easily.

4- Micro USB Port - This is common in most tablets these days, but the older Tab 2 line did not have micro port but the propriety wider port.

5- Screen clarity  Excellent, the colors are bright and the text is very, very clear. For me, I found this screen easy to read eBooks on and view internet pages.

6- I had a Tab 3 7.0 WiFi only and sold it to a friend, bought this one and find that it is a much better tablet.

7- This tablet runs so so cool! In fact it runs much cooler than other tablets I have used! It runs from 70 degrees to 89 degrees basically which is great. Even when I am on data or WiFi and downloading apps etc, it just BRIEFLY goes up to about 99.5 or so degrees. Then it goes right back to about 88-89 degrees. This is a very safe range and is normal. What I was testing for is to discover if at any time this tablet ran over 106 degrees --- it did not. When a device gets too hot, it will turn off and re-boot and when this happens often, it will damage the device.
**Having a low heat on this device is my favorite thing about this as I believe that this tablet will last a long time and not have to re-boot etc.

8) Lightweight and small enough to read my Kindle books and eBooks with comfort! When I hold up this tablet to read a eBook, I can hold it comfortably for a long time.

9) Fits so well in my purse or backpack, so easy to take places with me.
**I use a Finitie Tab 4 7.0 Cover/stand (Slim style) that I bought here on Amazon for 13 dollars and it is wonderful to travel with.

CONS (just one that I have found):
- Low internal storage - this tablet comes with 8GB internal storage (advertised). Because the OS takes up room, apps etc, take up room, the tablet just has about 4.7GB in the internal storage. This is not good because when you install an app from the Playstore, it goes onto your internal storage not on the External SD card. (The external SD card is meant for personal files such as your music, photos, home movies, etc).

**The GOOD NEWS IS: If you do not install a lot of huge games onto this tablet, you will probably do just fine with this storage.

Bottom line and Summary:

Would I buy this tablet all over again? Yes in a heartbeat! If you are looking to buy a MINI TABLET, this is the one that I recommend to you as I love mine!

Since I am a techie, you can ask me any questions in the comments under this review.

I'm coming off of an iPad 2 (march, 2011) and bought the Tab 4 7" because my 2-year-old basically confiscated the iPad to play toddler games. I wanted something smaller that I could hold in one hand for reading, browsing, and a few games here and there.

The first impression of the design was that it was quite good for the price. It's light, it's slim and it's utilitarian. There's no aluminum uni-body construction here, just plastic and more plastic, but it certainty looks acceptable and I don't need to worry about scratching all that pretty brushed aluminum. What's the point if you're just going to slap a protective cover on it anyway?.

Other impressions are that I like Android for it's openness compared to iOS. It may not look (by any means) as pretty, and it's certainly not consistently designed, but it works for what it was intended and I don't need Apple's "approval" to download an app that does something they don't agree with.

I also like the ability to use cheap SD cards for storage (BIG plus here), whereas Apple locks up memory into a completely proprietary $100/GB scam. The stuff is on the market for $1/GB, and that's for the performance RAM. 'Nuf said about the fleecing Apple has been committing for YEARS when it comes to RAM prices.

I'm not even going to complain about the paltry (these days) 1280x800 display. I don't need the extra resolution because my eye's aren't exactly what they used to be, nor do I want to pay for it. 1280x800 is acceptable, especially on a 7" tablet, which makes for halfway decent density. I can't see the pixels even with glasses, so it's good enough. However If I were reviewing the 10.1, I'd be hammering it for pixel density.

All that being said, what I really do NOT like about the Tab 4 is that it's FREAKING SLOW. My (almost 4) year old iPad 2 blew this thing out of the water. I can only imagine that the 1.2Ghz processor Samsung is using is 3 years behind the times and/or there's not enough internal RAM (1.5GB). Somewhere along the way they decided to save $10 and gimp what would otherwise be a no-brainier choice. You can't even browse a simple page without lagging and shuddering. If I had to do anything quickly on this thing, I'd send it back immediately and get a Tab "Pro", which looks to be twice as fast at 2 times the cost.

In the end, and as long as you don't care/need anything even remotely resembling speed, this is a reasonable choice. To the reviewer that said "Samsung has done it again!", all I can say is, done what? Barely updated the under-powered Tab 3 with another under-powered Tab 4? Seriously how much does it cost a manufacturer to use a faster processor of their own design and production? $5, $10?  Some performance would have made this a 5-star tablet at this price point. As it stands, It's a ho-hum tablet at a ho-hum price.

For simple browsing and app usage, this has been extremely reliable. It does have some lag while switching between apps and loading certain apps, but it is minimal and the actual apps themselves run smoothly. Streams video in 1080p reliably from several different apps.
I would give this crappy tablet a rating of less than 1 star, but unfortunately there is no option for that.  This tablet routinely disconnects you from the WIFI.  It is pure crap.

I love how this tablet functions, but at about a year, I lost speaker sound.  I can still hook it up to headphones or connect to a Bluetooth speaker, but that can be a hassle.  At about 14 months, the device started turning off when the battery level got to 30%.  Then it started doing it at 60%, and now at 18 months, it will turn off within 5-10 min if it's not plugged into the charger.  As long as it's plugged in and I don't need to use sound, the device still works great.  But, the whole point of a tablet is mobility, so it's lost its core function.  I've tried to get it repaired, but it would be cheaper to replace with a new device.  I'm hesitant to purchase another Samsung tablet because all the other devices have reviews similar to mine.  I've tried using a Samsung phone and iPad combo, and it's too frustrating to remember which button does what on which device.  So, I'll stick with my non-mobile tablet for now until Samsung improves the longevity of their tablets.

For the price, it's not a bad tablet. I do recommend Android devices, but although this is my second Samsung (previous model was a Tab 3), I've noticed several flaws with the brand.

Memory: the onboard memory is very limited. Moving your media onto an external SD card, where possible, does help, but Samsung loads this thing down with so much bloatware that your performance will be limited. You can turn off some (not all) of these pre-installed applications, but without rooting the device you won't be able to remove them. Some user-installed applications can be moved to the SD card, which frees up some space, but this often brings other problems.

GPS: The GPS on this device is, in a word, garbage. Even on a path with a clear view of the sky, a recent update of satellite constellations, and most active position poll turned on, accuracy is questionable at best. My pace data for a run under these circumstances constantly drops to 0 kph despite continuously moving. For run tracking or an that depends on the GPS like Zombies, Run! this is much less than ideal.

Positives: it's fairly cheap. The screen quality is great and the unit is light weight. Battery life is decent. There are lots of apps available that do a much better job than the pre-installed ones.

I am a big fan of the 7" size for tablets. They are large enough for comfortable reading and viewing, yet small and light enough to hold in one hand. I don't like carrying a large phone so I use a small phone for communicating and a 7" tablet for content viewing. After my Nexus 7 became to slow and laggy I began looking for a replacement. There are a few manufacturers still selling them but on the whole they are in the "low end" category with minimal specs and memory. There are both good and bad aspects to this. On the good side it means that they are cheap, fast enough for regular use and long lasting as batteries are not taxed. On the down side though, they have minimal storage and are underpowered for games or other high voltage activities.
In my case I'm not a gamer so the only downside is low storage. 8GB is pitiful in this day and age and even if micro SD is available in many cases apps only work in device memory. Fortunately in my case I don't use a lot of apps so can live with the 8GB's.
Screen resolution is always minimal in these low end models but I have found that 1200 x 800 is more than adequate for a 7" tablet and needs less power than higher res options. Some tablets come with 1024x600, which lessens the cost but is noticeably more pixelated, so best to stay with the former.
It finally came down to a choice between The older Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 or the newer Galaxy tab A. What I noticed is that the older Tab 4 is still selling very well and is becoming more expensive! Both have very good reviews so wondered why the older model is still so coveted despite it being stuck in Android KitKat.
The reason I finally chose the older model is because after reading many reviews for both I read enough commenting that the older model was better in some vital regards for my use (for example some people said that the older tablet had noticeably better bluetooth reception, a key item for me).

After a few weeks of use here is my report:
- After loading all the apps that I use regularly I still have 2Gb remaining so am ok in that regard. Also installed an SD card for media consumption
- I used developer mode to shut down animations and turned off Samsung Voice so there is absolutely no lag in performance
- Bluetooth is FAST AND FLAWLESS
-WIFI is VERY RESPONSIVE AND FAST. Websites load instantly and compared to other devices this one is as good or better than the other newer ones.
-Screen is beautiful, photos show up crisp and colors are very accurate. I keep brightness at 25% for most indoor viewing to save battery so by the end of the day I still have plenty of juice.
- Kitkat is just fine. As I only use the tablet for email, calendaring and basic media reading and viewing the older OS is more than suitable.
So in conclusion, the newer 7" A is an excellent device and has all the newer bells and whistles. But did not want to risk some of the complaints that users of both units have mentioned so went for the older model. No regrets.

I have a Note 8, a Note Pro 12.2 and all the Galaxy phones up to S6.  So I like Samsung. How they made a tablet without screen mirroring or the ability to use other USB drives by OTG seems to be intentional.  I couldn't figure out why I couldn't get my kids tablet to mirror the tv.  I thought it was me being stupid.  So I let them borrow my Note 8 in a silicone case, vs. the wonderful foam monstrosity this is in, so that they could mirror Cartoon Network.  They dropped it and shattered it to shards.  LOL.  So now, with this as the only working tablet in the house, I buckled down to figure out screen mirroring.  Guess what?  There is none. Samsung decided to intentionally handicap this tablet. You may be able to root it to bring back the functionality, but that's too much work for me.  I was giving it 3 stars.  Were it not handicapped, it'd be at least 4 stars. 7" is a little small.  I don't understand how 1 inch makes such a difference, but that still wouldn't be a deal breaker the way the lack of mirroring is for us.  Hope this helps someone.

I am surprised to see this is still being sold. All the glowing reviews are from 2014, and at that time I would agree this was a very powerful and full-featured tablet for the price. This device's nomenclature is SM-T230. You won't be upgrading this tablet to any Android version higher than the 4.4 (the most current version is 7) that it comes with as Samsung does not actively develop for this tablet any longer. What makes matters even worse, is CyanogenMod has not spun up a version for this hardware and no one else has either. Apparently, the SM-T230 is built around the Marvell PXA1088 CPU, and the information developers would need to spin up a kernel running a more recent version of Android cannot be gotten because Marvell keeps it closed source.

My Galaxy Tab 4 never really worked right. It was extremely slow and unreliable. Using google maps for more than a minute or two would crash the device and reboot. I recently dumped the stock ROM in favor of a custom ROM by Team Acheron, and the device now works well. Performance is fine and the google maps crash hasn't happened since.

In addition, the stock ROM is full of google and samsung bloatware. This device has 8GB of storage and most of that is tied up with pre-installed stuff that you cannot remove. Installing an SD card doesn't help because the system won't allow you to move many apps to that storage. Installing the Acheron ROM solved that problem as well.

This is an oldet model. I bought the exact same model in December of 2015 on Amazon for $137. Don't know why this seller's price is $50 higher a year later.
Price aside, I have had 4 of this model & have  loved them all. I am disabled & housebound. I read a LOT, so my tablets are in constant use. The only issues I have had are the charging port gets damaged easily. The metal blade inside bends, causing the plug to fit very loosely & not charge. The included  charging cables have very weak jackets which crack causing the wires inside to break which is another reason why they have charging issues. I think in my case, because I use my tablet almost constantly and while plugged in, charging I tend to be rough on them & that's how they get broken.
The internal memory is also misleading, it comes in 8GB & 16GB, a good deal of which is used up with the operating  system & preloaded apps. Many 8th the apps in the Google Play store are set up by the developers to automatically be stored in the internal RAM, which cannot be changed by the user, so the RAM gets used up really quickly, so an additional SD card is a must. They are expandable to 64GB, but I've found that 3GB  works fine for me, but I guess it would have to depend on the individual user.
Those few issues & the price aside, this an awesome tablet, that's great for using as a simple eReader, yet powerful enough to run just about any gaming app out there. I love mine & would be lost without it.

Bought for my 6-year old son for Christmas and he loves using it.  I debated on getting an iPad instead since we (the parents) use them, but didn't want to spend that kind of money for a 6-year old's device.
For parents, it isn't that great.  The parental controls are limiting and I find the Android OS a pain to use.  The device itself is a bit slow compared to others you can get now and the internal storage is terrible.  I installed a 32GB memory chip and constantly have issues with the device correctly utilizing it.  Did a lot of research to solve some of the problems I was having and apparently this is a common issue with Android (unless you want to hack the device or download apps you have to pay for - no thanks).  I wasn't a big fan of Android to begin with, but this device wasn't easy to work with.

The one thing i'm finding that I'm not a fan of is the keyboard, there apparently no autocorrect.  But I don't intend to do alot of typing on it.  Overall, very good little tablet for the price.  I even downloaded the Kindle app so have access to all my Kindle books.

Unhappy with this product for many reasons,  but the biggest problem was the CPU overheated constantly to over 135.  It doesn't have the capacity to be able to play certain games that I enjoyed, for example Candy Crush,  and many others.

This device has the portability of a phone with a big screen and a high memory capacity.  I bought this galaxy so that I had something to distract me in waiting rooms and places with free wifi.  As much as I love my 10 inch 2-in-1, it's far too big and awkward to just whip out anywhere.  And my iphone is way too small with not nearly enough memory for much of anything beyond music and taking pictures.  This offers a comfortable middle ground.  I can watch downloaded movies, surf the internet without straining my eyes, and customize it to do everything else Android offers.  I'm a woman and it fits comfortably in one hand.

So why is it pointless?  Because it really isn't THAT much better or more useful than a modern day cellphone--something most people own and are quicker to reach for anyway.  It certainly doesn't have a lot of power but it does have a good battery life.  Still, my 2-in-1 at least runs windows and thus can do things this device can't.  And an apple product of the same size and function at the very least has a decent camera (something this does not).  After the newness wears off, I wouldn't be surprised if most buyers struggle to find a use for it.  Besides the rare occasion I'm somewhere out of the house long enough to sit through an entire movie, I sure am having a tough time justifying this purchase.

The system gets a little jittery and slow while updating itself and apps (which pretty much every time you turn it on) so wait for it to finish updating before doing anything to avoid this.  Otherwise, enjoy.

This is my first ever tablet and in my opinion, there were large gaps in the instructions.  The MAJOR, HUGE problem that the tablet caused was that there was NO mention that syncing up my email with my laptop would completely eliminate ALL my emails and folders.  Every. Single. Email.  And according to my service provider, the emails are gone with no way to retrieve them.  Every single important email that I saved regarding my cancer treatment plan, my legal and Medicare info, my financial info.  It's all gone.  Thanks Samsung.  I know that I am hopelessly naive about using newer technology, but I would have expected some tiny mention of the fact that if you sync your emails, your system will switch your POP email to IMAP mail causing the loss of everything that's important.  As regards the rest of this review, I don't know.  I am so angry about the email fiasco, I put the stupid tablet down and have not touched it again.

I chose this mid sized Android tablet to serve as the screen to my drone controller. It first was the correct size to fit nicely in the bracket provided with the quadcopter kit. It also has sufficient processing speed, memory, screen resolution and brightness, and battery life to run the software, process telemetry, display the live video feed, plan autonomous missions, and most importantly- handle all of that without exception, and without running out of memory and thus freezing/locking up- which would leave me flying $3,000 worth of hardware blindly through the air. It also has a good gps chip, which is useful for any number of drone operations. Having said that, I think that mine is a fairly extreme application, and given the fact that this Tablet was so up to the task while being put through my outdoor torture tests, I have no reservations about recommending the Tab 4 to anyone. It will endear itself to novices, tweeting teens, app developers, and everyone in between.

I purchased this item as a Christmas present for my daughter back in 2014. I was happy with the price since I didn't want to spend much on it in case it would end up broken. After owning it for almost 2 years, I can say this was the most disappointing purchase I have ever made. The tablet didn't get as much use as I thought because it would constantly need to be charged, something I thought was odd since Samsung products usually have great battery life compared to Apple. Then it stopped charging completely, and I tried many different options, and even contacted Samsung directly for help. They gave me a few options as to what I could do to get it to work. Finally nothing worked, so I contacted them again and since it was under warranty I was able to have it serviced at no cost. We received our serviced tablet in October 2015, and it only lasted till March 2016. I am currently having the exact same issues, the tablet won't charge. Again I contacted Samsung but unfortunately, the item is no longer under warranty. We would have to pay $65 + $9.99 (shipping) to have it serviced. I decided that I wouldn't spend the money on having it serviced because I don't think the problem will be solved and I would rather put the money into a new tablet. The tablet was purchased mainly for my daughter to be able to use her ABC Mouse account and use it for learning experience. She is 6 going on 7 so the wear and tear was minimal. We bought the protective case to avoid any issues, After all that, my daughter was barely able to use it and now it's just sitting on a shelf collecting dust, I wish I would have invested my money more wisely. I could understand if I purchased a $50-$70 tablet, but I went with a name brand that is known to avoid wasting money but that wasn't the case. I would suggest, definitely spending the money. My other daughter received an Apple Mini 2 for her birthday and that was a year ago and have had no issues with it at all.

This is literally the WORST product I've EVER used. I will never ever buy Samsung/Android product ever again. I wanted to like this tablet so much. It's the perfect size and the screen and color aren't too bad either. But there's just too many negatives to it.

1. It's unbearably slow. For a tablet that's just 2 years old, the performance on this thing lags behind even older tablets. Changing apps or switching screens requires a lot of patience.

2. It freezes constantly. Any fast movement would often freeze the tablet, afterward it will crash and you would have to constantly reboot it again and again. My tablet got so bad that it's in a constant reboot, where it would freeze in the middle of a reboot and won't even boot up completely. This is insane. There's really no room for that type of bug.

3. There's not enough memory. While it's great that there's an external memory slot, using the external memory uses extra memory from the tablet and slows it down even more. Quite counter productive.

4. It can not handle multitasking as intended. Having 2 apps open at once while it updates some apps will sure to crash it. Seriously, why does that even happen??

5. There's too many native apps that you can't delete. The tablet only comes with 8GB and almost half of it is already used up for whatever reason and you can't even clear up the memory.

If you're planning to use this tablet to download apps or movies for your kids to keep them busy during road trips, 8GB is not going to be enough. Edited: In fact, you won't even get 8GB, because 3.28GB of that is already being used to run the system. Add the Google related apps that are pre-installed and you really only have 3.5GB of device storage. I thought getting a 64GB microSD card would allow me to install more apps but when you move an app to the card, you're really only moving part of it (an average of 15% of the app size). Most of the app needs to stay installed on the device in order to run.

I bought this item in October of 2015 from a marketplace seller. The sale itself was wonderful, tablet arrived quickly, and I have no issue with that. Fast forward six months, and I've noticed that has never been a firmware update. It's on 4.4.2 of KitKat. Lollipop is available and so is Marshmallow (you have to love Android's firmware names, seriously). After much research, Samsung is NOT upgrading the Tab 4, model SM-T230NU. Apparently it is focusing on 8.0 tablets and higher. Does that mean the tablet doesn't work? Of course not. But you'll never get firmware upgrades and that is already causing me issues re: storage on the SD card, game updates, etc. Buyer should absolutely be aware of this before purchasing. I wish I had been because I would have gone another route.

I DID NOT RECEIVE THIS DEVICE OR THE Lenovo Yoga 2 (8 inch) THAT I MENTION IN MY REVIEW FOR FREE OR A A DISCOUNT IN RETURN FOR A REVIEW. I AM IN NO WAY AFFILIATED WITH SAMSUNG OR LENOVO. .

I bought this tablet primarily to deposit checks into my bank electronically. My bank requires an IOS or Android operating system, for Android, they require 2,3,2 or higher. (this tablet comes with Kit  Kat which is 4 point something but certainly adequate. So , I installed the app for my bank, and there was no "Deposit Check" option in the menu of options. .I called my bank They told me that if the camera SUCKS, and isn't adequate for photographing the check, it detects that inadequacy and doesn't give you that option. .Turns out you need a tablet with an AUTO FOCUS lens and not a FIXED focus lens to  deposit a check THIS tablet has a garbage FIXED focus lens and I can therefore not use it for what I intended to use it for. I like that you can upgrade storage via a mini SD card (up to 32 GB according to Samsung but others say you can go as high as 64) .So, the camera SUCKS, you CANNOT replace the battery. (I hate that Samsung and others have followed Apple ,the KING of planned obsolescence ,and won't let you change the battery. On other Samsung models, ,you can't change the battery OR  the SD card Same with Apple .So, I returned this piece of JUNK and now bought a Lenovo Yoga 2 (8 inch) for $159.99 directly from Lenovo. WOW what a difference. MUCH stronger processor, MORE RAM. More storage space that is up-gradable via an SD card LONG battery life (Battery is not replaceable however) but the Lenovo is better in every way AND it has an AUTO FOCUS LENS so I can now DEPOSIT MY CHECKS ELECTRONICALLY YAY! Trust me, skip this piece of junk, spend a little more and get the Lenovo Yoga 2 (8 inch). NICE 8 INCH DISPLAY as well.
PS. .I also called Samsung BEFORE I made this purchase and they told me the camera was adequate for my depositing checks Their customer service sucks and they give out WRONG info .

I'm going to sound like the odd sheep with so many 5-stars here but was quite disappointed with this tablet.  Amazon had this on sale for around $120 which I ended up price matching locally but for a newer tablet with a great screen resolution I thought I could have another cheap tablet and not worry if it breaks in the next couple years.

First of all the device itself is solid.  Comparing with the Tab 3 the screen resolution is a night and day difference.  The battery life like as mentioned is great especially when it's just idling with the screen off it doesn't lose much charge which is very nice.  Being able to stick external micro SD card is nice as well.

I would've honestly traded the Tab 3's screen resolution for a snappier screen.  In fact I tried this stock ROM and used deodexed ROM but could not get the screen to respond quickly.  Sometimes I have to hit the button few times before the tablet would recognize my finger.  It got annoying really fast.  Then the lag continued and would drop out of Wifi within a foot range (hotspot through my phone) or randomly stop communicating with the host.

For this price I would've just bought the Nexus 7 (2013) as much as they had BT issue.  It's so disappointing; I thought I would give Samsung a try again but this tablet is NOT worth $150.  The response & the lag was just terrible.  My LG G3 phone is way snappier and faster than this tablet.
I love it besides the fact  that it lags a lot. Especially  when  I'm playing games. But it will work for what I need it for.

Overall, this tablet is great.  The battery life is quite long - several days on one charge.  Screen resolution is sharp and I have no problems with wi-fi or video speed.  The environment is intuitive, especially if you are already familiar with the Android operating system.  It charges from the wall in about 4 - 5 hours.  That seems slow since I have a fast charger for another device that works in less than an hour, but this tablet is not the latest model.

One con - for some reason, the sound keeps turning itself on no matter how many times I turn it off.  Also, it seems quite heavy, but that is to be expected for the decent battery life.

Overall, I am quite happy with my purchase, and the price was right.

I can't tell if every new screen I transition to is freezing up or if there's a problem with the touch buttons working right away when I migrate to a new screen, but I shouldn't have to (for example) tap an email 7 times for it to open. And that's 7 times with waiting a few seconds in between each try. Other reviewers here have mentioned this ridiculous slowness, so I don't think it's just this unit. I'll give it a few days and then may just return it --- unless I'm able to discover a setting change that rectifies this problem, this tablet is so slow as to be unusable for me.

You have to willfully slow down and focus on NAILING the mysteriously hidden sweet spot on every on-screen input button just to get this stupid TURTLE of a crap-gadget to respond to your finger input.  And when I say NAILING, I mean you have to hit it pretty hard, and most of the time, MULTIPLE TIMES to get an onscreen button to respond.  This is disgraceful and there is no excuse for a company as big as Samsung to put something out that is this embarrasingly low grade.

I cannot believe that I paid $150 for this hunk of poorly made junk.  Also, it is not compatible with many of the most popular games on the android market, such as Clash of Clans.  Ever heard of it?  Yeah.  So you have to change your settings to allow downloads from unknown sources and install a Clashofclans.apk game app just to be able to play one of the most popular games of all time.  And once you go through this annoying process, then my friend:  YOU ARE IN FOR A TREAT! And by treat, I mean TORTURE.  Playing Clash has never been more PAINFUL and SLOW.  But be persistent, and eventually the screen will respond to your endless stream of tap attempts.

Bottom Line:  try another tablet.  Maybe a Nexus 7 or Kindle Fire HD?  For being at the top end price point for a 7" tablet, this Samsung Tab4 is a bust.

Web browsing is decent and Youtube videos are smooth.  The brightness of the screen is still holding up well after so much usage when compared with some of my other devices.

There are some annoying aspects that pop up every so often.  The 8 GB of flash memory isn't enough for me and although I moved all the apps that I could move to the SD card, there is conflicting information on the amount of free space I have remaining. For the money, and as shipped, this is an excellent value.  However, there is a hidden flaw.  One of the advantages of the Samsung tablets is the IR blaster, which will allow the device to be used as a remote control for TV, Audio Equipment, etc.  I purchased 4 of these devices to use in this capacity in my business.  With the release of Samsung's version of Android 5 (Lollipop), the IR blaster feature is completely disabled.  Applications, even those bundled with the device by Samsung, simply cannot find the IR blaster on the device.  Samsung completely refuses to even admit that the problem exists, giving me an endless runaround and turning a deaf ear.  I've had trouble tickets open on this for months with no response of any kind from Samsung.  The problem has been well known and documented since early 2015, yet Samsung won't even acknowledge it.

If you are thinking about buying this tablet, beware.  Samsung has a website where they post their intentions about providing Android upgrades for their products.  The site promised an upgrade from Android 4.4 to Android 5.1 (which is a whole version behind current) in July, 2015.  As of February, 2016, they have not provided the upgrade.  I think it is pretty obvious that they have no intention to do so, but they are not bothering to update their website.  If you purchase this tablet, you will quickly find yourself so far behind the current release that applications will not work correctly and you will not be able to advantage of the newer Android features.  There are a lot of other tablets that will be as good or better than this one.  I bought one of these right after it was released (May, 2014) and I am really sorry I wasted my money.

I purchased two Samsung Galaxy Tab 4s to make them kid tablets. I added Armorsuit Military shield screen protection and NEWSTYLE shockproof lightweight tablet protectors and they have been the most incredible thing for the kids. Because it's android I have Google play that matches my account and we have not had many limitiations.  They have primarily been using these for their preschool studies using ABC MOUSE, but they also use them for games and YouTube kids and Minecraft PE and art. They have been fuctioning well for 14 months of constant use and kids toughness. One even survived being washed under the running faucet! (The protective foam helped) These have been powerful enough and versatile enough to not give us any headaches, and many hours of peace, as well a solid educational and artistic start. These are awesome for travel too. They don't have removable batteries but they do have easily accessible SD card ports so you can load them up with kids favorites. Samsung has a native app called Kids Mode that is fun by itself and integrates cameras and media very well. It blocks certain apps it feels aren't for secure enough for children like regular youtube or purchasing apps, but thanks to youtube kids it's no longer a problem. We also have used Kids Place by Kiddoware as an app for the the kids tablets too. Also since these are Samsung tablets they are great for mom and dad to use when they aren't.

Purchased this during the summer.  My previous tablet was a google Nexus 7 which I liked for almost two years. It didn't have an expansion slot and I never rand out of space. I loved this new tablet at first. The hardware is snappy and responsive. The screen is bright and good angle viewing. No issues with the hardware it's the best one yet.
What breaks this tablet is the size of the main drive and the restriction of what apps you can store on which drive. You only have 8Gb of space most apps for some reason have to be on. You can not use your SD card so your drive fills up rather fast with data and apps. There doesn't seem to be a rhyme or reason as to what apps will use what drives. It's quite arbitrary. Because of this the device is worthless unless you want to just store movies and TV shows on the SD card. The other issue that completely breaks this tablets usefulness is the restriction on OTC devices and usage of the USB port. This device will block any attempt to add USB storage. I've had 3 expencive 64Gb USB drives that work on older tablets but refuse to be recognized by this device. they have blocked this functionality entirely from what I can tell. No drivers work from any company. If you use this just for reading it's a very nice tablet at a good price and a good recommendation. If you are a stargazer and active person with varied interests this will have you frustrated and regretting the purchase very quickly. There are a few other smaller restrictions I've found that the Nexus doesn't have. Main being the Samsung skin on android is just that meant to restrict your ability to use this device the way you want or need too. And advertizing that you don't own this device that you paid for so you can't use it the way you need to. Only the way they want you too in their ecosystem. Then there is updates that never happen. Would I buy it again? No.

If you're thinking this is the poor man's iPad Mini, you've got the wrong tablet. I own two iPad Mini 2's for home use. This one I keep in my work padfolio (hardly adds any bulk to the padfolio), and as my workplace has abundant WiFi, this is great to browse the web, check out social media, play a game or two, or check email, and they're awesome to pass the time in an airport, as the battery life is pretty good. The seven-inch model is very easy to hold in your hand for reading, and the screen resolution is very good as well. The single speaker at the rear of the tablet isn't the greatest, but you could throw on a set of Bluetooth headphones and be set. The front and rear cameras are basic, and there's no flash on the rear. This tablet is runs on Android KitKat, and probably could use the Lollipop upgrade, but if it's that important, you should probably buy either a different Android tablet, or the 4G-LTE version of this one that has a better chipset and has already received the upgrade to Lollipop. Apparently, Samsung has forgotten to throw out the upgrade for the WiFi version.

For the price, this little tablet is hard to beat, plus Samsung products are pretty solid. I'd much rather pay a little more for this over a non-name brand tablet, even though they're probably all made in the same Chinese factory. As long as you run this thing lean on apps and keep as much as possible on a MicroSD card, this is plenty fast for basic use.

What a piece of junk. I purchased this for a friend and now I'm embarrassed. It's slow, laggy and spits n spudders at the slightest of finger swipes. It's 2016, my 2007 iphone ran smoother than this crap. Simple web browsing is NOT smooth. Video playback is terrible (choppy). Games take forever to startup and run like do-do. This is my second android/samsung device and it's very disappointing. My friend that's in the know told me I needed to "root" it and remove the crap stock software that's slowing it down. So I did that, no change in performance. The person I got this for is constantly bringing back to me for various reasons (before and after rooting before you try to blame that). Either the sound wouldn't work or the wi-fi would keep disconnecting. Now the keyboard is freezing and keeps typing letters with accent marks above them. Imagine trying to type in a password when that going on... Also, the speaker is on the BACK??? WHY?! The people behind the tablet can hear it clear as day, the person using it, not at all. It almost requires headphones but if you disconnect/reconnect headphones too many times the sound quits working all together and requires a reboot to work again. Absolute crap. Can't believe I wasted money on this and now have to waste my time on it. Should have just done what EVERYBODY was saying and get an older ipad mini for $60 more. May still do that and use this as a doorstop/birdcage liner. Guess it's a good "starter tablet" for someone so they appreciate the actual tablet (apple) they get next. You get what you pay for. Write that down

I bought the Tab 4 7 for my kids as a Christmas present.  The major downfall of this device is the internal storage, as many on hear have mentioned.  8 GB of internal storage is ridiculously low when you consider the OS itself takes up over 3 GB.  With the device running on Android 4.4 KitKat, writing and moving apps to the micro SD is restricted, making the expandable micro SD slot useless.  The only way to work around not being able to write to the SD card is to root the device, therefore voiding the warranty.  Not happy.  Might return it and just upgrade to the Tab S2 or Ipad with more internal storage.

Samsung Tab 4, 7 inch  Easily Adaptable!

A year ago I purchased this unit at Costco to determine if I could replace the weight of my lap top in my back pack while traveling through the Middle East and Europe.  I found this to be a very helpful, light weight, tool in quickly searching and obtaining WI-Fi, composing logs, obtaining photographs and videos, and ease in downloading and sending materials.  Although, I still have not got use to the word processor and the word/spell correct mechanism, I prefer this unit to my other devices.

Due to the fact our homes have WI-Fi it was the perfect gift for my wife who is challenged in computer skills.  Therefore, I purchased this unit again for her at 33% lower cost than what I paid 10 months earlier.  The only difference is her unit did not come with a sleeve case as mine.  I was very surprised how she managed the unit for in one week without my assistance she was e-mailing, watching Netflix and dictating with the unit.  Unbelievable adaptability for the novice!  If you need a light weight simple unit that has great features without connectivity to expensive data 4 G, this is the unit.

I think these are great for kids. I bought 2 of them for mine and they absolutely love them.

Pros: Pretty cheap tablet. Runs ok most of the time .Very portable. Runs most games without any lag. External sd support so you can pop in a sd card to add music and movies to it. Battery life is great as well.

Cons : 8gb of memory ends up being like 4gb free for the user. Games are getting huge in size so my kids have to constantly uninstall stuff to make room for new stuff. Sometimes it'll lag but what can you expect from a $150 tablet. Screen isn't the best but again price.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend it if you're getting this for your kids or if you are a light user whos only going to be using it for simple stuff like web browsing and YouTube. If you're a power user I'd definitely recommend a spending the extra money on something a little more powerful and with more internal space. I have the Galaxy Tab S 10.5 and it is an amazing tablet.

First of all, Amazon sent me the 10.1 inch tablet instead of the 7-inch I ordered. Although surprised, I was ok with this and Amazon never contacted me about this. So just know that this review applies to the 10.1" version, although I think it would be the same for the 7". I have been satisfied with this table, but have run into one major frustration over the last couple days. I wanted to find out how to connect the tablet to an HDTV (not a SMART TV) via HDMI cable. Sounds simple enough, right? Well, unfortunately it turns out that there is no satisfactory way to do this. The capability to connect to an HDTV via HDMI was inexplicably not built into this tablet, although both earlier and later Samsung Galaxy tablets have this capability. I spent a lot of time trying to find an adaptor that would work. I called Samsung, and they said they don't make an adapter for this tablet, and to go ask at Best Buy. At Best Buy, that's where I found out that the necessary functionality to connect to an HDTV via HDMI was not built into the Galaxy Tab 4s. He said the only solution is Google Chromecast, but this turns out to be unsatisfactory as well, since each app must choose to build in the capability to use Google Chromecast, and the apps that I want to use on the HDTV do not work with Chromecast. So there is literally no way to connect this tablet to my HDTV. Very frustrating and very hard to understand why this is the case.

I bought this tablet primarily for bluetooth music streaming using spotify. The tablet does support the aptX bluetooth protocol despite not being listed on the websites etc on the topic, the aptX logo is right on the back of the box for this tablet (see photo). Streaming works great to my NAD - D 3020 Integrated Amp which also supports aptX. I will say initially I experienced some very frustrating issues with wifi on this tablet and my home network setup which was pretty standard. There are numerous similar instances described by people in forums etc just google it. The fix that seemed to work on my end was to change the security protocol on my Airport Extreme router to WPA/WPA2 which enables both the newer AES and older TKIP encryption. Previously I had it it just on the AES option. I also had to do a hard reset of the tablet. Once that was done and the setting change it seems to work well on wifi.

Don't get me wrong, I like this tablet. I just don't "love" it.

The screen is nice and large for a 7" tablet. The color saturation is very nice and pleasant to read. Cranking up the visibility all the way looks brilliant (although not recommended as it will drain the battery faster). I set it to about 80% and its just fine.

Battery life is very good. Its way better than my HP Venue 7". I'd say thus far the battery lasts at least another 20-30% more than my typical use of my Venue. By design, it is much thinner and in turn lighter. Its my go to tablet now replacing my old Apple iPad 2 which is a klunky and tires out my hands because it is too heavy if holding onto it for long periods.

What I don't like about the Tab 4 is the hard button location. It is fixed at one end of the tablet in portrait mode. Most of my usage is in landscape mode. If you ever used an Android tablet, you know the navigational buttons appear in software menus along the bottom edge of the screen in the appropriate mode. You always know to just tap the bottom edge and the menu appears. But not with the Galaxy Tab 4. This poses a problem when you are using the tablet at night in a dark room! You can't see the buttons. Samsung should have lit up the buttons to make them visible. Or better yet, just leave the software menu navigation in place by default. For those who use an Android cell phone, you are not going to like this.

The other problem with having these buttons along the inner bevel is that you can hit them by mistake. There is not a lot of bevel real estate available along the sides of the tablet. There has been so many times that I have been holding the tablet in landscape mode where i accidentally touch the buttons that it triggers their action modes. This is really a bad design in my opinion and why I give this 3 stars..

Another thing I don't care for is the layout of all the apps on the screen. There is no way that I can find how to sort the apps by name. Because they are randomly ordered its a real pain in the butt to try to find the appropriate app. Eyeballing left to right, top to bottom, and swiping across multiple screens is a really poor way to search.

The tablet worked fine for about a day, then it began to act up. The display would become distorted, then power off. When it came back on, the display was blank and black. The only reason I could tell it was on was by pressing the Home button to see that the backlight comes on. I contacted Samsung and had to factory reset the tablet.

Once that issue was resolved, the tablet began to disconnect, then reconnect to Wi-Fi every 30 seconds or so. Contacted Samsung again and another factory reset. If the issue happened again, they referred me to the Samsung experts at Best Buy. As luck would have it, the Wi-Fi issue began again as well as the screen issue.

I went to Best Buy and they were going to attempt to flash the tablet. I received a model that was not serviceable in the US. The Samsung guy pointed out that instead of saying "Model" on the back, it said "Modelo". Also, there was a "NOM" logo/icon on the back that was not on the Galaxy Tabs in store. Since it was unable to be flashed, the only resolution I was given was to return the tablet for a refund, although it was well within warranty.

I'm sure this is an isolated incident, but this was my experience with the tablet. I'll purchase one from Best Buy instead, just to be sure if anything happens, it will be able to be fixed in the US.

tl;dr: Not ideal for high-end modern mobile games, very comfortable design for casual use, low on memory (get a 16GB or higher Micro SD card), was shipped two devices with dead pixels.

I work in the gaming industry and I have very frequent exposure to mobile devices, but the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 was the very first tablet that I purchased for personal use.  I originally purchased this device hoping it can at least run Star Wars Uprising, which I learned that it does, but not do very well, but for the price I paid, I somewhat expected this.  The device is pretty sleek and lightweight and has been fantastic for watching Netflix/Amazon Videos, Email, Facebook/Facebook Messenger, and random Googling.  I would recommend getting at least a 16GB micro SD card because the tablet lacks memory.

Long story:
The real problem follows my experience with Samsung's support agents and their lack of understanding with mobile devices (primarily their own) as well as their own policies.  I've read many critical reviews on Amazon warning about their Customer Service, but you see that with any product so I continued with my purchase.  My device arrived with a dead pixel and while it didn't affect the functionality and mostly forgotten, I decided one day to look into the Samsung policies regarding how a dead pixel gets serviced.  My search ultimately led to me contacting their support personnel through the Samsung chat, which I was able to engage with an agent immediately.

I explained that I had purchased a Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 on Amazon a week ago and it arrived with a dead pixel and I while it's just a minor aesthetic problem, I was wondering if they can do anything about it.  The agent didn't attempt to outline my options and went into straight into "script mode" and began instructing me to do extraneous tasks (which I was respectful compliant about until a point), such as: restarting the device, insuring the OS was up-to-date, plugging the device into a wall socket, and then eventually suggesting that I reset the device to factory settings.  All this for a dead pixel!  At this point I made clear of my technical background and my understanding of the standard procedures of technical support (because I do both) and was very certain these resetting my device to factory settings was not going to resolve my issue.  He then instructed me to go to a URL to report my issue, which didn't load and he asked me to try to install a different browser to try again.  When it didn't work he asked me to try another computer---didn't work.  In the end he decided it was best that he filled it out for me, which I wish I knew was an option before spending 25 minutes installing different web browsers on two different computers.  And the end he told me to take it to a Best Buy for a free replacement.  This whole conversation took 40 minutes so when I was asked to fill out a survey over their service, I decided to keep it up to get back to later.

I went to Best Buy and explained the situation to one of their Geek Squad personnel.  He quickly knowledged my story and told me they would replace my device, but unfortunately because I bought the device from Amazon, the device they have has a different SKU from the ones they have in stock and they are not able to take in the device for exchange.  However, the agent mentioned I should be able to get a replacement from Amazon without any hassle, which in retrospect I should have done in the first place.  On my phone I was able to get a replacement sent to me after only a few seconds of navigating.

I returned home content that a resolution was on the way, I filled out the Samsung survey with a disapointment rating, which they never received, due to an error saying something along the lines of "survey no longer valid".

I really wanted to help improve their customer service by giving them my feedback with my experience so I decided to contact Support again to explain what happened.  After doing so, the Support personal went into "script mode" as well and began asking me about the details about my device and attempted to instruct me to doing other things with my device even though I have already referenced my Support Ticket that should have shown that we've been through this process already.  At that point I just left because I've consumed way too much time dealing with Samsung Customer Support.

Amazon shipped me a new device before I could ship my defective one back.  Unfortunately, the new unit had a dead pixel too!  At this point I consumed way too much time that I care for that I'm just going to deal with having a tablet with a dead pixel and look into dropping the extra cash for an Apple device.

This is my first tablet and i love it so far.

It's been only two weeks and i cannot give you a full review yet, but i can say below confidently:

I have not used my laptop much since i got this. I don't have a smart phone, but this is like one without phone service or connectivity, i imagine.  Only time i use my laptop anymore is when i have to do heavy duty typing, organize my pictures and music, and when i want to print something.  Emails, skype, net surfing, do it all on tablet.

If you are used to apple products and never worked on Android product, it will take a bit of time to get used to, so it will require some patience.  It seems like everything is customizable.  Pro is you can personalize it to almost exactly how you want it to function. Con is that you have to go through so many setup options to get there. Default setting is okay, but definitely spend some time on setup to conserve battery and turn off annoying notifications.  If you are not familiar with Android and don't want to mess with setup much, apple maybe a better choice.  But don't discount this option just yet.

Google play (app store) is setup to auto update all apps. It seems to slow down device and sucks battery. To turn it off, go to Google play store, setting (top left corner of the screen), and turn off auto update apps.

Screensize is about x4 of iPod touch screen (not the whole device, just screen)  A person with a larger smartphone may think 7 inch tab is just an extra large smartphone without phone and be unsatisfied.

Not a fan of the soft keyboard, but you can download different keyboard apps to solve the issue.  Two things i do like are: numbers are part of the main keyboard, and language option.  So many languages.  I can type japanese just like on a regular keyboard, which is huge.  (I still haven't found a keyboard app offers this AND has better english typing experience)

One cool thing about this tab (maybe if this is standard in all tabs??) is you can set up different users like computer.  Everything is completely split.  Even pictures you take won't be available for another user to view (though for our case we wish it was a  shared album)

camera is ok. Low light takes poor picture, but just change the mode to night and it improves quality quite a bit.

If you have decided to buy this product, make sure to also purchase:
Screen protector
Tablet case
Mini SD card

mini SD card, so that you can move downloaded apps to it to save storage. If you have a card inserted, all pictures you take will be automatically saved on the SD card.  The tab comes with 8GB storage, and the mini SD card i got for 10 dollars on amazon adds 32GB more.  Tab comes with pre-installed apps you cannot get rid of, so 8GB doesn't go very far.

Packaging was eco friendly with 100% post consumer recycled paper, printed with soy ink.  100% recyclable. This was not expected and was a big plus for me.

If you are like me who wants hands on experience before deciding, go to your local store and play with it first.

I think this is a perfect tab for a beginner with tight budget like us.  The price has come down so much since now there is a newer tab called S, but it still seems like a very well built product and i am very satisfied with my first time tablet purchase and experience.

***addtitional info as of 12/26/2016. About storage, fun apps, and more
This tab has Android 4.4.2, Kitkat. What i have read says that starting with this operating system they started preventing some Apps to be moved to SD card.  I downloaded photo edit app, which i was able to move to SD card, but the photo i edit won't save on the card. I downloaded an app that imports library from my iTune account but it won't save the music on card. The reason for this restriction is speculated to be in effort to promote and encourage consumer to use Cloud service.  2 years of service is offerred for free with this tab (or maybe for a new samsubg user?) Anyway, i worked around to save music on SD card, and it is fine, just take extra time.  There are some apps that helps you move these non-movable apps, (search under SDCARD FIX), but it doesn't solve all issues and some required more tech involvement than i was willing to invest my time on.

IF you are trying to hook up your tablet to a mini projector or any HDMI, this tablet doesn't support the functionality.  There is no adaptor out there that could do that either.  I believe newer device supports it, but you have to make sure you check whether HDMI is supported or Video Out is supported for it to work.  This is one big disappointment for me.

IF you are trying to download Apple Music, this device is currently isn't compatible either.  the Apple Music app is in Beta stage, so it may change, but i won't be surprised if it just ever doesn't get supported. Seems as though there is a lot of limitation built into this device.  I was buying this to test out to see if we like a tablet in our household.  Now I see all the things a tablet could possibly do, I wish it did all of that.  With that said, if I had known all of this and I would like having tablet around my household, I would probably have shelled out 50+ dollars to buy newer tablet so that I could do a lot of things that this tablet isn't letting me do.

I think I got greedy with functionality. This tablet still is good for the price and if you aren't looking for the tablet to do all the things that $200+ tablet would do for you, this is still a really good tablet. :)

Now let's make the most out of this cool little device.  Here are some free fantastic fun apps to consider downloading:
Pocket - any online materials you may want to read later, just "share" via Pocket (instead of facebook, twitter, and such), and the article will be saved on your Pocket app and read it offline.  Youtube videos are viewable  when you have internet connection only.

Sony sketch-turn your tab into a drawing board, sketch pad, canvas, and create your own scrapbook page, greeting cards, and simply let your inner artist come through and shine!  This is a far better app than game apps if you are looking to kill time.

Photo Director-this app does so much and take your already-proud-of pics to a whole another level!  It can also make your less than ordinary picture  a piece of art!

iSyncr - if you are still a iTune lover and you have lots of music on iTune but you want the library on your device, this app will do the job for you.  The free version will limit you to transferring 100 songs per transfer, but you can do as many transfers as you need to.  Also you will have to transfer the music to the device first and then move the music files to the SD card afterwards - it's due to the whole SD card thing I talked about earlier.  Yes, it's not as convenient, but it still works, and the transfer is fast.

Musixmatch - this is an app that shows you lyrics of the music you are playing from your music library.  It's cool.  There is a function that works just like Shazam, music identifier and also displays lyrics at the same time.  This app is actually a really cool music player app, so instead of using the built in music player app, I use this app as default.

Crackle - shows Sony Entertainment TV shows and movies.  Selections are not anything like NetFlix or anything like that, but it's FREE!  I love watching Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee, which is Crackle Original and hosted by Jerry Seinfeld.

Avast products - they are really good app to keep your device protected, cleaned up, saves battery, and it's free!  Install Avast Mobile Security, Avast Battery Saver, and Avast Cleanup.  It's amazing how much junk get saved and take up your limited memory by simply browsing internet and Play Store

First, let me say the obvious; for $100 this isn't cutting edge electronics so temper your expectations accordingly.  Having said that, this is a nice little tablet for the price as long as you keep it simple.

PROS:
Crisp display and at 7" a nice viewing area.  Steams movies well with very minimal issues.
Comes with quite a few bells and whistles (so-so camera, assortment of apps, and some nice features such as weather updates and news)
Great for reading newspapers, books, and surfing non-graphic intensive web pages.

CONS:
Virtually no storage area, buying an expansion card is almost a must
Not powerful enough to play any graphic intensive apps.  Tried playing a simple app like Simpsons Tapped Out and it's very choppy and stutters.
Not a fan of the button placement but getting used to it.

Overall I'm happy with it.  I got it as a handy tablet to look up information quickly without going upstairs and starting my desktop computer.  Yes, it has it's limitations but I didn't spend $500 either.
Wish I had bought  a  bigger  SD  card  but even with  my measly 8 g card it holds everything  I need for work plus some games!

This is a great tablet in a lot of ways and the price is good considering what you get. But there are a few drawbacks which would lead me to not recommend it. First, the camera is mediocre at best, which was surprising considering how good the camera is on the Galaxy phones. But the biggest issue I have with this tablet is the internal storage. It only comes with 8GB, which is actually only about 4GB when you factor in the space required for the system to run. So you only have 4GB of internal storage to work with, which gets eaten up very very quickly with apps and photos/videos. So you will need to purchase a memory card to expand your internal memory, factor that into your purchase. But even with that, it doesn't really solve the problem. You can move apps to the SD card, which frees up space, but you have to do it manually every time you download an app, it doesn't happen automatically. And even with that, certain apps (like the pre-installed Google Apps, most of which I'll never ever use), can't be moved to an SD card. My son has had the tablet for just over 2 weeks and the space problem is constant, even after purchasing a 32GB SD card.
While this tablet is a performer, the battery charge doesn"t seem to last as stated.

I bought this tablet at Costco over a year ago. At first I really liked it but it only came in white and that took some getting used to. Many people complain about TouchWiz but it hasn't bothered me. I also don't use it though. Lately it's been feeling a little sluggish as I've become accustomed to doing more with it, however I'm also a power user.

There is one glaring problem with this tablet that surprisingly few people mention but that you can easily find with a Google web search and it's totally mind boggling that it has this problem: the buttons. They're at the bottom of the screen as if you'd be holding it portrait when likely everyone while be using it landscape. Older tablets had no physical buttons so they moved on screen when you rotated the tablet. The Note series has them on the side as you'd expect to be holding the tablet that direction. But not the Tab 4, they're on the bottom and it drives me nuts!!

Why is it such a problem? You have to reach other them to use the screen and they're capacitive sensors so you don't even have to touch the buttons to active them, not that it's hard to accidentally do that either. I'm constantly exiting out of programs or bringing up the list of programs and it's a real hassle when you're trying to play a game and it has to reload afterwards. There's no way around this problem except to root the tablet as far as I can tell, which would invalidate the tablet against software updates in addition to being an unsuitable solution for a majority of the buyers. It would be really wonderful if the buttons could be disabled in landscape mode or if on screen buttons would appear instead. It's soooo annoying!!

This tablet makes a nice video player but has three significant problems:
- Samsung does not release software updates. Every month new security bugs are found in Android that only get fixed in Google Nexus devices and the nicer Android phones. Galaxy Tab tablets as far as I can tell do not get security updates, so every month it gets more and more risky to browse the web or even open emails on this tablet. UPDATE: the Sprint cellular-ready version, model SM-T237P, has 16 GB of RAM and can be updated to Android 5.1 even without any cell service, but the WiFi-only version with 8 GB of RAM, model SM-T230NU, is stuck with Android 4.4 including several security flaws.
- The tablet is sluggish. While video playback is alright, many apps run slowly.
- 8 GB storage is not enough. In theory many (but not all, not even most) apps can be moved to an SD card, but I have found that none, not even major apps like Facebook and Kindle, are able to be moved to the SD card. Android needs at least 16 GB of storage to work well. UPDATE: see note above. At least one seller here is shipping the cell-ready Sprint model which has 16 GB (even though this listing is for the WiFi-only version).

I wanted to like this tablet but I ended up returning it.  There are a number of things that hold this tablet back.  On the positive side, it is a great size for commuting and can easily be held in one hand but the is pretty much where the good stuff ends.  On the bad side, the display is only 1200 x 800 which is not that great for watching video. I also found screen glare to be a big problem when trying to view videos outside.  Second, there is a ton of bloatware on this device which you simply cannot delete.  Too much memory is devoted to junk software nobody wants and you are left with just a few Gigs of memory free for other stuff.  You can add an external SD card but as others have said, there isn't much you can actually move from the device to the card due to the version of Android OS this thing runs.  I did some more research and ultimately decided on the Asus Zenpad S 8" with 64GB of memory and 2048 x 1536 display.  It costs almost $300 but was worth it.

So I have had this tablet for about a week. I bought my first one from Walmart and my girlfriend ended up liking it so much I bought her one off here. Hers hasn't came yet but I figured since hers is the same exact model that I should give a review on this tablet. I find this tablet to be a good buy for the money because first of all its thin and light. Is it as thin as a iPad air? No its not but its thin enough and small enough to where I don't feel this when I carry it around to the store with me or to a friends house. Its about twice as thick as a iPad air 2 but twice as light (at least thats what I think). I also REALLY like how the back isn't some shinny crappy plastic that smudges and scratches really easy. It has a very nice textured back that feels really good to hold in the hand. One thing of many things I don't like about the physical design is that Samsung still uses that fake chrome looking design around the tablet. I wouldn't mind this to much if it didn't chip so easy. On the second day I have had it the chrome looking plastic chipped it bummed me out a little bit because I am very careful with any tablet, phone, laptop and really anything computer like because I understand how easy it is to break them. The other thing that I don't like at all is that for some weird stupid reason Samsung decided to put the only speaker on the back of the device. I don't like this because since it is so small its easy to cover up with your finger or hand and once you do you won't hear a thing. Just because the speaker is small don't mean its not loud. I do like the speaker itself because for such a small thing it is pretty loud you just got to make sure you don't cover it up when you are using your device. I do like the speed overall most apps load quickly and run without a problem. You have to keep in mind that this is a budget friendly tablet so don't expect to play some demanding 3D apps because its not made to replace your Galaxy S2 tablet or your iPad air. Its made to be affordable with decent specs and thats what this has. I have played angry birds, fieldrunners, air hockey, chess, ect. Overall the performance is great with these games. One thing I did notice is that it is a tad slow when it comes to using a browser like chrome or the stock Android browser. What I mean by this is that when I swipe up on my tablet to go down on a web page it takes close to a second to execute the task. Its not bad enough to make me not like the tablet its just annoying sometimes. I do like the screen. Its has a resolution of 1280 by 800 so it won't set the world on fire but its good enough to work for me. Color reproduction is great and the screen is nice and bright I also like how I can look at the screen from different angles without having to deal with polarization. The cameras on here are fine I don't expect much at all when it comes to the camera quality because this tablet is a lower priced tablet. The back camera can record 720p video and the front I believe can record 480p. So video calling should be fine selfie pictures will suffer due to the lack of camera quality. This tablet does not support OTG which was another small bummer but oh well Im glad this tablet has a micro SD card slot which can take up to 64 GB!! Yes I have tried this and it works with no problems. One HUGE plus about this tablet is that battery life is just flat out amazing! I can get around 2 to 3 days of normal use (web browsing, playing some games, watching SOME youtube, going on Facebook) and get a day with heavy use (youtube for hours, gaming for hours). Standby time is really good to if I have the tablet on all day in standby with 100% Id only lose 2 to 3%. I ended up buying a otter box for this tablet for $40.00 today and so far I am really liking the otter box. It don't add a ton of weight and I love knowing that my cool little tablet will be protect from any falls and scrapes. I will do a separate review on the otter box sometime soon. So far I think Samsung is doing a great job with there tablets. I bought the Galaxy Tab A 9.7 inch with the S pen about a month ago and its working wonders its very fast, the screen is bright and I love the screen ratio and size of the screen. I have also reviewed the Galaxy Tab A so if anyone is interested in reading it just click on my profile and then click on reviews by me. But back to the star of the show. I feel like the Galaxy Tab 4 7 inch is a great buy if you want something to play some lite games, to watch youtube, browse the web, check email, read books and really just anything simple. If you are looking for a tablet to game with Id recommend the Galaxy Tab S2 or iPad air 2 both have higher resolution screens, much faster processors and better graphics with a higher price tag.  Below I will list the pros and cons about this tablet.

Pros
1. Very small and light making it easy to type with 2 hands.
2. Better build quality than the Galaxy Tab 3 7 inch
3. Micro SD card slot can support up to 64 GB (I have tried this)
4. Very good battery life. About 2 days use
5. Good standby time
6. Bright, crisp screen with decent resolution (215 PPI)
7. Speaker is loud for such a small speaker
8. The price is right! LOL

Cons
1. Speaker is placed in a stupid location
2. Chrome plastic chips easy
3. Can lag using a browser
4. Cant update to Lolli pop without rooting it
Light, fast. easy to use. I just love it!

I love it!  Works great as an e-reader (I bought it to replace my old Nook - and am very happy with it).  Battery life is excellent. Works great for Skype and many other programs.  Wireless connection is fast.  Overall a good tablet.

The stock video player is a bit wonky, in that it's hard to go forward or back - the same is true when watching online videos.  I also don't care for how Samsung "groups" programs. When I group apps on my LG phone, they come together in a folder icon, whereas this tablet will cluster them in a hodge-podge.  Not annoying enough to kill the sale, but there are better arrangements.

My only complaint - which technically isn't the fault of the tablet itself - is that it comes with a ton of bloatware, or perhaps, just things that I'm not going to EVER use.  These items are not removable, nor are they able to be moved to my storage card.  The system memory and base apps, along with the 12 - 15 apps I've added, now only give me 1.5 GB of open space.  Which seems to be okay - until I want to download an Amazon movie for an upcoming flight.  Suddenly, I'm out of space.  You have to be very discerning with which apps you want to load and which you don't need.

Yes - I did know that it was only an 8GB machine when I bought it, but I had no idea that the base system would gobble up so much of that space and that none of the pre-loads could be removed (which I think stinks)

This sort of thing is happening more and more often on Amazon - vendors neglecting to mention their goods are refurbs, or that shipping will be six to eight weeks from China, or the 12 five star positive glowing reviews all have the same spelling and syntax mistakes and are clearly plants.

After seeing the incredible success & growth of Samsung over the last few years, I figured I should finally give the Galaxy Tab a try. For the size & features at this price point, the product seemed like a no-brainer.

I'm afraid to say that after using this tablet for a few days, I'm literally shocked at how horrible this thing is. Menu response, app loading, and page changes are all incredibly laggy and slow. But the worst part is the sluggish, stuttering screen performance, especially when scrolling. Pages like Facebook, tumblr, and news sites that use WordPress styled infinite scrolling are absolutely painful to use. Every attempt to scroll up or down results in jerky page movement that is just agonizing to look at.

With the surging popularity of Galaxy tablets & sales of these units in the millions, I assumed they must be a viable alternative to the iPad. But after using one I can only conclude that they must be popular because they are cheapnot because they're any good.

If I can't return this thing to Amazon it's going on eBay faster than you can say "junk."

I bought this product after spending time looking at many different tablets offered by other companies. I originally purchased it as a device to keep me entertained during my long flight to Europe. I have owned the product for over a year now, and although it was expensive, I think I have gotten a great value out of it. I use the tablet mostly as a device for reading books through the pre-loaded Amazon Kindle App, but also sometimes use it just to play games or check up on my fantasy football team.

Advantages:
This tablet runs on a very advanced, but easy-to-use android operating system. I did not have a very hard time adjusting to the way the system works even though I had been using Apple products for some time prior. The battery life of this tablet is also very good, lasting for about eight hours under heavy use,  which includes playing games, reading books, reviewing school materials, etc. The product is also very light, weighing just a bit more if not the same amount as my phone. I had a few questions when setting up my tablet and called the Samsung support team. They were very helpful and actually took control of my tablet remotely in order to answer my questions. The team is always standing by, and that is a great comfort.

Disadvantages:
I have noticed that this tablet is hard to read in the sunlight. I have taken it to the pool in order to read a book, and found it difficult to read unless I was sitting in the shade. I have yet to drop this tablet, but the fact that it is so light somewhat scares me to the point that I am not sure it would survive the fall, so I make sure to be extremely careful.

Overall Assessment:
I chose to give this tablet five stars because I absolutely love it. I have not once regretted my purchase of this product, and would be more than willing to recommend this tablet to both my family and friends.
