Android version 4.4 (Kit Kat) created restrictions on what apps could be stored onto the external SD.  Hopefully we will see if 5.0 changes it.

If you thought that you would buy this tab and then get a 32-64gb micro Sd card for storage...think again.  Very few apps can be moved onto the SD card.  After Samsung puts all of their proprietary apps onto the internal storage, you are left with as little as 1gb of storage for your own apps.  The result is a tablet with a constantly full internal storage and empty external storage.  Mine filled up after adding 5 apps for work.  I was unable to install anymore apps.  That is pretty pathetic and renders any Android 8gb tablet pretty useless if you want to put more than a few apps on it.

Go for the 16gb version or buy a Nexus 7 or newer 32gb (which is faster).

Update: if you are a even little bit tech literate you can root your tablet (voids warranty) and download apps that will enable moving apps to your SD card.  This allows you to fully utilize the external storage as you ought be able to.  The tab still gets 1 star because out of the box, 8gb is not enough to have a fully functional tablet that enables you to use all of its features.  Sad that Android went the way of Apple with their tyrannical restrictions on what you can do with your own hardware.

This tablet was laggy and lacking in wifi connection consistency and response time. The screen would freeze up very often when trying to touch an app to launch, touch a text area to type, switch from the letters on the keyboard to the symbols, or even trying to enter a lock screen passcode. That last lockup would take at least 30 seconds every time with the screen flashing on and off twice. Abysmal. I know it's a fraction of the price of our old iPad Mini retina display and it has something like 6 times the RAM, but holy cats, the iPad blows it out of the water every single time in usability. I cannot go back to barely-limping-along performance. I guess there's a reason we shelled out the big bucks for the iPad (and for an entry-level Macbook Air for that matter), and that reason is probably the software Apple produces. When you want fast and responsive and reliable, vote with your wallet and don't skimp.

Other negatives--the screen looked horrible after using a retina display, the internal RAM filled up in less than a day, the chrome looking plastic edging around the screen chips and dents very easily, and the back got very hot over where I'm assuming the processor is located playing a Facebook game.

I received this tablet as part of a promotion, and it's honestly not bad. Sure, the camera is shoddy, there's no ambient light sensor, it only comes with 8gb storage, the speaker is tinny, and TouchWiz sucks; but, the display is bright and vivid, you can expand your storage, GNL runs well on top of TouchWiz, and, if I had paid full price for it, the price would be low enough that I wouldn't be bothered by the drawbacks.  All in all, it's a solid, if completely unremarkable, tablet that gets a lot of mileage as an e-reader, streaming movies and music to a chromecast, social media and e-mail machine, and occasional remote control.

If you need a cheap tablet to use as your living room tablet, I'd say it's good enough, for you.

I've been using Apple products since the first iPods came out.  We have a dozen Apple products all over our house and I've never had any trouble with any of them.  My reason for moving to the Samsung was 1) I like the smaller size of this tablet better than the iPad mini 2) the tab 4 was $50-$100 less.  After spending 10 years with Apple, maybe part of my dislike for the tab has to do with my familiarity with Apple?  But any of my Apple products I've owned have all seemed much more intuitive.  It took me 10 minutes to figure out how to delete an ap.  They way the windows are set up, especially as you start adding apps, seems very random.  I had apps showing up all over the place.
The other thing that I noticed is that the touchscreen doesn't seem to be very responsive.  Or, maybe it just takes a lot longer for the device to do its "thinking?"  On my iPhone the icon will light up, so I know the touch has been registered, but with the tab 4 I got nothing.  Not even just on icons, but trying to tap/touch within a page.  It seemed not to register at all sometimes.
Compared to the iPad the camera is a waste.  I had flip phones that took better pictures.
The last complaint that I have is the lag.  This device is not suited for gaming, IMO.  There are a couple of games my son really enjoys on his iPad, so I installed them so that he could play them on my device as well.  One of them is a continuous game - you're a block and you have to jump over obstacles, and the lag was so bad that the game was pretty much unplayable.  He was in tears in 5 minutes because the levels that he could do on his iPad were stumping him.  Even a game like candy crush, I often had a lag in falling candy.
The only plus is give it over the iPad was the google play store, so not even a compliment for the device itself.  I liked that we could utilize the free apps without having to have an account.
For someone who has never used an apple, this device may seem fine, but, imo, you'd really be missing out if this is where you landed.  I will never buy a Samsung again.

After my 2012 Kindle Fire HD kept disconnecting from wifi and kept giving me "authorization failed errors", I decided to upgrade my tablet between a Samsung Galaxy Tab 4, Nexus 7 (2nd gen) or Samsung Galaxy Tab A. The Galaxy Tab A was too expensive. Even though the specs are better on the Nexus 7, I went with the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 (16gb Sprint model) because the price was actually far cheaper than Nexus 7 and I heard way too many complaints about slow down/bricking Nexus 7 after lollipop update. I have been very impressed with the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4.

Pros:
1. User interface is very user friendly, fast and responsive. I am a big fan of lollipop on my Moto G (2nd generation) so it was easy to get used to this operating system. This Samsung kitkat isn't that much different than a stock android lollipop like my Moto G. Samsung kitkat operating system has a lot of features and it is very easy to use. I hear that this tablet may soon get a lollipop update and that will only make it better for me.
2. No bloatware... I heard some people complain about way too much bloatware. I don't think that is true at all. You get google apps that you can easily delete if you don't want. There are like 12 Samsung apps that you can't delete but I wouldn't call them "bloatware" as they are camera, calendar, galaxy apps, gallery, video, settings, etc. and I wouldn't want to delete them anyways. It isn't like you get 30 apps of locked junkware.
3. Great picture quality screen... Don't be fooled by the 216ppi. At a 7 inch size, the picture quality looks really great. It is the same 216ppi as my kindle fire HD and that too looked great. Sure you can pay more for a better screen but I don't think it is really necessary.
4. High quality construction... It has a nice feel in the hands and the quality is top notch. I have always been a samsung fan because they are really known for high quality and reliable products. This product is no different. I don't think Asus quality can compare and I heard many complaints about Asus costumer service too.
5. Cost... For me, I got it on sale for much cheaper than the retail price and way cheaper than Nexus 7 too.
6. MicroSD Card compatible... 8GB is way too little for me. I have the 16GB model and I already used 7GB of storage after installing all my favorite apps. If you want to add pictures, videos, music, etc., you will definitely need to use an MicroSD card. All tablets should be able to use MicroSD cards in my opinion.
7. Camera... It doesn't take amazing pictures or videos but the quality is good for the very few times that I use it. I don't think camera should be a real major priority for a tablet. Phone? OK. Tablet? No.
8. Battery life... I think the battery life is better than my Kindle Fire HD.

Cons:
1. Speakers are somewhat lacking... My 2012 Kindle Fire HD has much better, clearer and far louder speakers than this 2014 Samsung Galaxy Tab 4. The speakers aren't terrible but when I did a side by side comparison, the Kindle Fire HD was really much better. This surprised me especially because my Kindle Fire HD was from 2012.
2. Capacitive buttons... It isn't that big of a deal but I would prefer the on-screen buttons like on Lollipop. In the dark, it is hard to see but you do get used to them by feel. I guess the benefit of the capacitive buttons is that they don't take up some of the screen space like the on-screen buttons.

I would highly recommend this tablet and I would give it a 4.5 stars out of 5.

Mostly good.  I'm coming from a Samsung Galaxy S3 phone and the phone is better or the same in every area except screen size.  The 7" screen on this is wonderful for watching YouTube videos. What I did was get a nice Clipster blue tooth speaker and pair that whenever I watch a video or stream music.

I have a regular 802.11n router.  I did read people were having trouble on the newer band, but my connectivity is good.

I like this and have in a nice otterbox case which I carry in my cargo pants pocket everyday.  I wouldn't return it though some days I'm tempted to go back to the S3 since I don't need to carry an extra speaker with that.

It has a nice strong battery.  At first I was disappointed that I couldn't replace it but I found that I typically only have to charge it every other day.  Typically I'm just using at work to check on emails with WiFi.  On the weekends when I watch a lotta videos it lasts a day.

First of all, I enjoy the thin wafer-like feel to the tablet. The controls are situated well and the 7-inch size is perfect, especially if you use the tablet for reading a lot. The device itself is a top quality product I would expect from Samsung.

The reason I gave it only two stars though is that the 8GB is clearly not enough space to run a reasonable amount of apps.  Samsung loads the tablet with quite a few uninstallable apps which are not necessary and which use up a lot of the 8GB of space that the tablet has on the device. The SD card that I purchased for it, which contains 20GB of space, is nearly useless due to the fact that many of the apps can't be moved to it so the problem I'm facing now is that I'm quickly running out of room on my tablet where I'm having to choose now which necessary app I need to remove. When I first purchased it several months ago, I was able to put a few apps on it for entertainment along with the apps I use for checking my mail, getting on the Internet and reading (Kindle app). I have a couple productivity apps like a task manager app, OneNote and Evernote but beyond that, they're either all pre-installed Google apps or pre-installed apps I never asked for. Thus, as the apps on the device take up more room due to constant updates, I'm finding that I'm having to uninstall apps I need that make the tablet useful.

I upgraded to this tablet from my nook hd+ and I am sooo happy I did. the battery life is amazing, a full charge lasts about 2 or 3 days depending on how much I use it. I bought it to take with me on trips so I wouldn't have to lug my computer around, and its basically just a much larger version of my phone (galaxy s3)  I would recommend this over a nook any day. Simple 2D games like Angry Birds had noticeable low frame rates compared to Nexus 7 or my basic phone.  Samsung UI is a bit much, but does have a lot of options and works well on a tablet.  The tablet fits perfectly into your hand and is light so therefore it is very comfortable to use, but the back surface is a very slippery plastic.  I know it is a budget device but this back surface makes the tablet easy to drop.

In the end, the very slow GPU and slippery surface made me return the tablet.

There are two things about the Tab 4 that I wish could have been better.  The main one is that it doesn't have a strong of a connection to the wireless router.  The router is placed two rooms away from the bedroom and the Tab 4 regularly maintains only 1 bar whereas the Tab 2 connection was always strong.  I also wish that the softkeys on the bottom of the Tab 4 would light up.  Sometimes it takes a bit of hunting and pecking to find the right spot to hit for the return key.  Other than these two limitations Samsung has made a pretty good product.

Samsung Galaxy Tab is great all around. The only issue is that it drops WiFi a lot and I have tried working with my WiFi router to combat this and its been doing a lot better now. It may have something to do with a Android update not 100% sure but I am leaning that way.

I just got this today and maybe I am not using it correctly, but this is not working like I hoped it would. I wanted a tablet but no more Apple stuff. It is sloooooow as if operating through a dial up modem. Time consuming to download apps and it often doesn't complete the download. Get error messages about connectivity and my WiFi connection, yet my phone, Kindle,  laptop, and Amazon Fire work as usual. I will write to Samsung, but doubt that will result in anything positive. Frustrating device. I would not recommend this regardless of price. This is an update on July 25th.  I figured out that if I was sitting right on top of my Wifi router this thing worked like a champ.  If I got more than 20 feet away, I measured it, the device started losing connectivity.  At 25 feet and beyond useless.  I started dealing with Samsung for a fix.  I have to say I spent at least 6 frustrating hours working with those people.  It was reminiscent of the dawn of the home computer age in the 80s, spending hours on the phone with tech support.  Every phone call or electronic request you make with those people you start over.  That is to say another recital of the model number, serial number, name, phone number, etc. The on line forms are especially laborious. They acknowledged I had a problem, and sent me a "ticket number," which I was to use to get further assistance.  One would think you simply referenced that number in your next communication and all of the pertinent information would be available.  Not the case, fill out another form and start over.  Samsung will attempt to convince you the issue has to do with your internet connection and/or your router.  They will want to walk you through disconnecting everything, reconnecting, rebooting, restarting, ad nauseam.  I quickly subverted this time consuming, time wasting process by telling them all other wireless devices were working fine throughout my house, including my Galaxy phone. Ultimately, Samsung agreed to let me send it in for repair.  One fellow finally admitted there is a hardware issue with the device.  They emailed me a UPS mailing label, which I couldn't print, but ultimately figured that out and sent it in.  About three weeks probably, we'll see. Update on August 2.  I received this back from Samsung in exactly one week.  I tracked the progress through Samsung's system.  The device was repaired the day they received it.  The tab works a lot better now, but still has occasional connectivity issues.  It was suggested to me to relocated my Wifi router, which I did and that has provided some help as well.  For the price, it suits my purposes now.  I still say though, if you need a reliable tablet, pony up extra $$, and find something else.

These 7" tablets are the best size IMO. They can pretty much go anywhere, even in your back pocket or purses for women. As a photographer, this size helps keep the amount of gear I carry light. It's just too bad they don't seem to think anyone wants this size anymore and don't offer the new tabs in this size. I guess with the phones getting bigger, I can see the logic. So this will probably be the most powerful 7" Samsung tablet at least for a while. The operation is smooth and flawless. There's lots of after market accessories to choose from. The size also makes it easier to hold like a book as opposed to the larger one's where you need two hands usually. So what's not to like and why did I give only 3 stars?

This tablet does NOT support USB OTG. So the only thing you can plug in to is a power cord. Not even able to connect to your computer. Transfers to and from the computer have to use the microcard. No thumb drives, external keyboards, controllers, etc. Wow, turns out that's a deal breaker for me. I need to be able to download images from my camera to it. The older 7" tab 3 had OTG support, the larger 8" and 10" tab 4's have it, but not this one.

Do yourself a favor and get the SM-T235 or the SM-T237P tablet and you'll be able to connect all the devices you probably just assumed you could. Oddly enough, all the tab 4 7" models sell for around the same on ebay (respective of condition, etc) except the 231 model which goes for a little more. But I'm not sure why as it does no more the these 230 models. Get the 237P model made for Sprint which has the OTG support, 16gb internal and LTE if you want to pay for it and if not just use it as a wifi unit. I bought a like new 237P for $85. What's really interesting is I can turn it into a phone if I want which I might do to see what it would be like. I know when enabled, this LTE is super fast since it has Sprint Spark which is said to tap into all three Sprint-LTE radios in the 800 MHz, 1.9 GHz, and 2.5 GHz frequencies.
I think it will do what I need.

7.5 Its a mostly solid performer with  quality, is very typical Samsung with an all plastic construction and a fake leather back that still feels like plastic.  Despite its plastic construction it feels very solid and sturdy with a very nice amount of weight.  Samsung has also trimmed down their use of chrome on the Galaxy Tab 4 line up making the design look much more aesthetically pleasing.

As the name suggests, on the front is a 7.0 inch display with a resolution of 1280800.  Its not super high resolution so pixels are noticeable, but its certainly far from a bad display as its very bright with good color reproduction, easy to see outdoors, and  has great viewing angles. Internally its being powered by a 1.2 GHz quad-core processor, 1.5 GB of RAM, and 8 gigs of internal storage which will run out quickly unless you augment by micro SD expansion.  Theyre very mediocre specs and the overall performance throughout the OS is passable with very few hiccups.  Graphically demanding games are still playable but its certainly far from buttery smooth.

Just like the rest of the tablet the camera is nothing to write home about.  Its a 3 megapixel fixed focus camera so photos are very low resolution meaning you won't be able to zoom and crop due to the lack of detail.  It does fairly well with plenty of light but once you take it indoors photos become grainy especially in low light and with no autofocus the camera struggles to take clear shots.

The biggest highlight of this tablet is the battery life.  Its packing a 4,000 mAh battery inside and it lasted me about 2 days under heavy usage as I primarily used the tablet for gaming with some light web browsing and social networking.  At the end of it all I wound up with slightly over 7 hours of screen on time which is quite impressive so I have no doubt this tablet could last between 3 to 4 days with average use.

The Galaxy Tab 4 7.0 ships with Android 4.4.2 KitKat out of the box with Samsungs TouchWiz interface.  TouchWiz is still TouchWiz, but the version on the Galaxy Tab 4 line up is much more slimmed down.  Many features found on Samsungs more high end offerings like My Magazine and Air Gestures are not included, but all of the more useful features like multiwindow, palm swipe, and smart stay remain intact.

 Its small, portable, and cheaper than Samsungs PRO line but it isn't without its shortcomings.

I bought this in March 2015 for my son. He went in half and I went in half for his birthday.

We chose this tablet because of the high reviews and because it was less expensive. I was hesitant to buy a device with only 8Gb of storage because I knew it would get sucked up so fast in games, but then I found the 32Gb SD storage card and thought, no biggie. We will just dump all apps and stuff onto the external storage and it won't be a problem.

There are a lot of good things about this tablet.
*It runs well.
*The screen is very well lit and clear.
*It plays Netflix and YouTube videos very well.

There is one huge issue that I do not like and that continually frustrates my son.
*The storage issue of 8Gb EVEN though we have an additional 32Gb SD card.
*The pre-installed bloatware that you can't get off (but you can uninstall updates and turn off).

We ran out of storage quickly. I thought, no biggie. We have the SD card. However, what I did not realize even after looking into the SD card for about 1 hour on various forums is that you either have to A) Have an app to MOVE EACH photo or video or app onto the SD card B) Go into Settings and Applications and move each app individually -OR- C) Plug the device into a computer and manually move stuff onto the SD card.

I do not find the manually moving of the files convenient at all. And, now, even more frustrating, we keep getting an "insufficient space" when trying to install an app even though we have moved every single thing possible to the SD card. We have also uninstalled the updates and turned off all the bloatware. So I am installing yet another cleaner app and then I will try again plugging the tablet into the computer and manually moving things.

I also own an iPad 3rd gen. It has a mere 16Gb of storage. When we run into storage issues, we delete apps that we haven't used in a long time. There are no caching/memory/storage issues on the iPad. You delete it. The space is back. You use it again. I have owned the iPad for 5 years without any issue. So, I am very frustrated to have a 4-month old tablet with storage/cache issues already.

I think if the SD card is to be used at all in a user convenient fashion, you should get a choice of where you want to install your apps in the Google Play Store (or whatever store you choose to use) and it should be easy to switch your storage of photos and videos to the SD card. Also, when you move the app, your app data should automatically follow! As in, you should be able to go into settings and say, "Store my photos and videos on my SD card" and "Store my apps on the SD card." and "Store my app data on my SD card." Android is not making this easy. Why?

After this, I find that had I known, I would have forked over the additional $$$ needed for an iPad or iPad mini.

I Ordered this tablet as a graduation gift for my brother. After 20 minutes of setup, my brother set it down and checked his phone. When he picked the tablet back up, the internal LCD Panel was cracked (no damage to the body or glass of the device, in fact we wouldn't let my brother use it until he had applied a case and a screen protector), the top half of the screen was moved to the bottom half, and the  top was black.
So I contacted customer service, was refused a replacement, but offered a repair. I didn't want to chance sending a defective device in multiple times, so I asked if I could there was any way I could get a replacement. I was given a ticket number and transferred to executive customer care. It rang twice and hung up. So, I called back, offered up my ticket number, and was transferred again.
I spoke to a rather rude representative, who insisted that because there was some sort of physical damage to the device, the warranty was void, and I would have to pay for a repair. I explained that there was no outside damage to the device, the problem was obviously internal and not the result of any misuse. He insisted it was void no matter the source of the damage, so I pulled my copy of the warranty and asked him to show me where it said that any physical damage automatically voids the warranty, no matter the source. He pointed me to clause A of the section of what is not covered, which states that any damage resulting from misuse voids the warranty. I explained to him that my brother was using the tablet like anyone normally would, and pointed him to clause B, which states that any damage is void, unless caused by Samsung. Since the damage was internal and not from misuse, it would have to be a manufacturing fault, meaning Samsung was at fault, and it was covered for at least a free repair. He then pointed me to Clause G, stating that "defects caused by operation" were not covered, glossing over the "improper" part of that sentence, as well as the fact that that clause refers to software. I pointed this out. He insisted that his information was correct. I said he was acting upon interpretation and taking phrases out of context, and asked to speak to his supervisor. He said that they both use the same resources, I would get the same response, and hung up.
Anyway, I kept calling and eventually ended up with a free repair, so I'm going to send it in tomorrow, but if anything goes wrong on their end, or they deem it "irreparable", they'll contact me and give me my "options", which probably means they'll hold it unless I pay $50 to get it back. I am never buying Samsung again. Spend a little more and get a Nexus 7, trust me.

This is just a preliminary review.  I got my Tab 4 on Wednesday.  I immediately started playing with it.  I fully charged it. I set it up according to my preferences. I registered it with Samsung. I paired it with Bluetooth to some of my other devices.
I was impressed with how sharp the screens were. It was way better than the Tab 2 it replaces. It was a lot faster than my Tab 2.
It was delivered at about 7:30pm and after playing with it for hours, I was tired and went to bed. The next morning I wanted to try out the IR Blaster.  There wasn't one!
I never used the IR Blaster on my tab 2, so to me, the lack of one was no big deal, however I hate to be taken advantage of and I felt that TechGiant (fulfilled by Amazon) sent me a slightly inferior product.
TechGiant had good reviews and most customers gave them good ratings. I felt I couldn't go wrong getting my Tab 4 from them. I even gave them a 5 for fast delivery.
After discovering the lack of the IR Blaster I thought about the strange things I encountered when I received this. Usually an item like this comes in a sealed box.  There was no seal on this box. Usually, there is warranty information inside. There was only a quick start guide. When I powered this up for the first time, I was greeted by some instructions written in Spanish. Fortunately I looked at the drop-down menu and figured it was telling me (in Spanish) to choose a language. Later on, all temperatures were displayed in Celsius.
I couldn't help but think TechGiant sent me a tablet designed for another country.
I contacted Amazon. They offered to exchange this device. At this point, I haven't decided. I have gotten items from Amazon for years and Ive returned a couple of items that were grossly problematic.
If I end up returning it or not, I will post an addendum in a few weeks.
I have posted some photos illustrating some of the points I made. I have given this three stars for now.
Addendum: After I wrote this review I looked at a photo another buyer posted.  He said that Samsung no longer included an IR Blaster in the Tab 4.  It is advertised as being included. The Amazon associate I chatted with said it is included. What gives?

Absolutely love this thing. I use it in the medical field to look up patient information and to have notes readily available. I like that it has a MicroSD slot where I can store all of my music, notes, and documents. Fits in my white coat, my scrub pants, and even my jean pockets very well, which makes it excellent to have on rotations since every spare moment to study counts! The battery life is EXCELLENT. If I forget to charge it one day, no big deal, it'll last me two. Though, charging it every night is a safer bet. Things that make it so affordable: lack of flash light; no automatic focus on camera; relatively poor quality cameras on front and back; screen resolution. All of these are NOT IMPORTANT. Seriously, if you need to take a photo, use your camera, or phone. Don't be THAT GUY who takes pictures with their tablet. Nonetheless, it is nice to have a camera on it, just in case you want to snap at something interesting, which I've never had to. So who cares if it's poor quality or doesn't focus automatically. The screen is supposedly, not as "crisp" as others, but I find it to be indistinguishable from any "retina display" out there. It is also extremely bright, if you want it to. Brighter than my Galaxy S3. Obviously still difficult to read in direct sunlight, but doable. The speakers are pretty descent for a tablet. Overall, it was a GREAT investment, especially for the price.

I was extremely excited about getting this tablet for my daughter for her birthday, and she was equally excited to receive it. The form and structure of it was what I was expecting, nice glass display, good response from touch, colors looked sharp and everyone was happy. We loaded Netflix, Disney Tsum Tsum, and another game TanTan. I thought everything was fine, until I saw her going back to one of our old cell phones to play this TanTan game. I asker her why, and she said that the game would 'glitch out' on her. I though no way, the tablet should have much better specs than my old Samsung Note 2. I tried it out, and there is a definite delay in most all her games. All her games with motion were sluggish, choppy and moved unpredictably. I thought maybe it was something that she installed without me knowing, so I did a factory reset, and install just one game, Tsum Tsum. Still the same choppy, sluggish mess. I was very disappointed. We own ton of Samsung cell phones and have never had really any issues like this. I am returning the Tab 4, 7" and I don't care if they charge me a restocking fee... I have no use for a poorly made/designed product like that. I give it two stars because it streamed Netflix videos fine, and browsing looked sufficient. We ended up getting an Acer Iconia 8" for the same price and it is leaps and bounds better. The games are smooth, video definition is higher and has a very cool aluminium shell. She is a happy camper now.

This tablet is definitely useful as I just lost my smartphone and have to use an old one from years ago; but using it as my main smart device I've noticed a plethora of issues.

-When plugged into an AUX cord the audio will distort if turned up too high. I don't mean distortion like usual when audio is played too loud through speakers, the audio is terribly broken. I can play music through the same speakers at a louder volume than this tablet can produce without issue.
-The WiFi and Bluetooth will randomly disconnect (it still says I'm connected to an access point but I have no internet access. I have to disconnect and reconnect to fix the problem).
-The front and back camera's are absolutely terrible. It looks like a Nokia from 2005 + no flash or autofocus.
-The tablet will lag and freeze up from time to time. Switching from app to app is a hassle, even when its only two apps open.

Unfortunately by the time I realized these problems the warranty had expired. So I have to focus on the good things about this tablet:

-Battery Life: A single charge will last me all day even on heavy use. I can go two days on a charge if I use Power Saving Mode.
-Perfect Size: The 7" screen is the perfect balance between screen real-estate and mobility. I can fit it into my pocket with ease. People keep asking me if it's a phone with a surprised look on their face.
-Water Resistance: It doesn't say it on the product page, but if a drop of water lands on the screen it stays a drop. If I move it around it doesn't leave a trail of water. Note: Not water PROOF.

I think if mine didn't have the defects I listed at the top then I would definitely recommend this product. Although I can't say if these issues are exclusive to my tablet or if they all have these problems. If you think you want to try it out be sure to keep the warranty in mind.

We have owned this tablet for a year. We have probably gotten less than 15 hours of total usage out of it. We went to charge it tonight and turn it on to use and it will not charge or turn on. It is completely dead. Not worth the money to have a device die completely with such little usage.

The "bloatware" pre-installed by Samsung takes a little over 4GB of the already limited total 8GB available. Purchasing a separate SD card doesn't help because Google doesnt allow you to transfer apps to the SD card - has to stay on internal memory. In fact, this is such an issue with the Galaxy Tab 4 that if you google "Galaxy Tab 4 memory issue" all kinds of help tickets will come up regarding how COMPLETELY USELESS this tablet is. I've had this tablet for a few days now and after you update the requisite Google apps, like Gmail, Drive, etc. you are left with 500MB or so for anything you might want to do with the tablet. Also discovered that when you have less than 400MB the tablet won't let you even download a small movie due to space constraints. Basically, you have the space for 1 thing non Samsung/Google at a time. If you want anything more than that you will have to uninstall the 1 thing you're currently using to make space for your new 1 thing. Ironically the memory booster app I installed took up more space than it was able to clean, because again, the ENTIRE tablet memory is consumed by Samsung pre-installed bloatware and the memory booster saw it as essential. I was very surprised by the high praise in Amazon reviews as a simple Google search turned up these problems, and they are fairly ubiquitous.

I received this as a gift from my parents. Usually when I receive a gift I won't be too harsh. I got this because my Nexus 7 broke recently before that. And for a tablet that you would buy last minute, it's pretty fair. But I use this everyday and there is so much that bugs me about this device. First let's talk about the memory on this device. It is advertised as an 8GB device. However, you are running Android and Lollipop side by side so that takes up 4 of the 8 gigabites. Then there are a bunch of pre-installed apps. Now we only have roughly 2-3 gigabites. While this is a fair amount, if you use your tablet for work like me, you'll find yourself downloading apps for work and school and you barely have room for anything else. The camera is crap but that doesn't bother me because I have a real camera to take photos with. The touch screen is very odd; it can either be really sensitive that if a crumb were to land on it, it wouldn't notice to it's so insensitive it wouldn't notice you jam your thumb through the screen. The touch screen is one of my main issues. Let's say you have an app where you have to hold down your finger to do something. I'll use Minecraft as an example. In Minecraft you hold your thumb on the screen to remove dirt. Often times however, the touch screen doesn't let you hold it down and you can only tap. This seems to be a thing that occurs very often and can be very frustrating.

TouchWiz is a very annoying program. Since it is run side by side with Android you get holes in TouchWiz and all of a sudden Android appears. I'm not saying that Android is a bad thing, I actually prefer it over TouchWiz, but the consistency  is sooooo bad on TouchWiz. It has no idea what it wants to be. If everything was TouchWiz in this device I wouldn't be as mad. I just want consistency.

The back of this tablet is very smooth. This might sound like a pro, but it is actually a con. With no grip on the back, the tablet feels very slippery too hold, which could lead to a cracked screen. So you're going to have to spend another 15 dollars on a case if you want to keep this hunk of junk, Which is pretty common today.

This tablet has two good features: price and screen. Everything else sucks.

1. Slow,slow,slow. Everything is jerky, even Candy Crush. Switching apps takes a lifetime. Opening up a new app even more. Keypress takes up to a second to be recognized.
2. Samsung's Android flavor is just unbearable. All configuration options are thoughtfully arranged in the least logical fashion, and grouped in several inconvenient tabs that make little sense.
3. Back button is on the right, not left as in vanilla Android devices (Google, Motorola). This might be a matter of preference but I find it not intuitive at all.
4. Android 5 Lollipop? No way.
5. No custom ROMs are available for this device (save for repackaged Samsung ROMs that essentially is the same thing less bloatware) due to Samsung's infinite wisdom in deciding to implement heavy-duty protection for this chipset.
6. Bloatware. Then some more. And more.
7. Did I mention its slow? It will often ask me for PIN code twice after booting, in immediate succession.

Disclaimer: I am running the latest version as provided by mighty Samsung. There may have been miniscule performance improvements in last upgrades, but even if so it barely makes a dent.

What can you say....It's an excellent tablet with a great reputation.  I use it for watching videos, email, and mild internet surfing.  It is a great bridge between using a smart phone and breaking out the laptop when you are sitting around the house.  Everything works as advertised; I can use it for days on a single battery charge (although I don't use it everyday); and the screen res is way better than what I need/use it for.  My only complaint would be that it could really use a better camera.  If you are the kind of person that carries a tablet everywhere, takes pictures, and blogs/journals about your experiences....then I might look elsewhere (unless you are cool with a camera that only works decently in perfect light conditions with minimal resolution). For the casual user though, this can't be beat.  The price is right; the quality is great; Samsung is reputable; and it just feels and looks good in your hands.  Make sure you pair it with a high quality screen protector right away. Like I said, for the money, the display is great so don't take any chances with it. Just for the sake of saying so...I have used this for about 3 months now and am extremely happy.

Have all the people giving this tablet 5 stars never owned an iPad?  This is a low budget, entry level, slow, slow, slow, tablet. I would say it's ok if you're on a budget, but if you have the cash, look elsewhere. For the price, I think it's fair (hence the 3 star rating), but man is it slow. So unresponsive. Every app launch, swipe, or press...there is a lag. We're an Apple family. We have iPhones, iPads, Macbook Pros, and Minis throughout the house (not that you care, but just so you know where I'm coming from). I thought I'd give Android a try just to see what the fuss was about. Bearing in mind this is a very low budget tablet, I had low expectations on it's performance, but wow, this really disappointed me. I mean, my daughter has an old iPad 2 circa 2011, and it is noticeably faster than this. This Tab 4 feels cheap in your hands, like a slab of plastic. I think the screen is made of champagne flute glass as it shattered the first time it was dropped from about 3 feet onto kitchen floor tile. If you're thinking this would be adequate for a child, I would say get a used iPad instead. You may have to pay a premium for Apple products, but they're built better, last longer, and don't come preloaded with Samsung bloatware. I realize this costs about half an iPad Mini and I would say the iPad Mini is twice as good.

Again, if you don't have the budget for an iPad or even Nexus tablet, this might be adequate, but keep your expectations low.

I rated Samsung Galaxy tab 4 four stars because it is a good overall tablet. This is my 3rd tablet, my first was a Kindle fire 7 inch, my second was an iPad 3Rd generation10 in. and now the Samsung Galaxy tab 4  7 in. Model. This 7 inch model fits perfectly around my hand and is lightweight compared to my heavier iPad.  The speed and performance for general web browsing is excellent, although I am not a heavy game player, so I could not review on the speed of those games.

The flaws, is that Depending on the site, you can not accurately scroll up and down, example Hotmail or other websites. Like the iPad,  you can not view flash videos, so when your on facebook, you can't see them or download flash player. Or play certain app.s like Dream Box mathematics App. This charges quickly but the battery seems to use up even when it's idle and not in use. The battery is not as efficient as the IPad.

Overall, I'm not a tech specialist, but am overall pleased with the price of $139 for this speedy Samsung Tablet. It does the job for Web browsing, light APP usage, checking emails and Facebook. I love the overall feel, look and performance of my new tsblet, well worth the price even though it have minor flaws.

I waited a while to enable me to use the device before writing my review.  I recently bought a Lenovo 7 inch tablet, which I was initially happy with.  That failed to work suddenly and Lenovo would not honour the guarantee.  My loss.
My wife swears by Samsung and so I took the plunge.  Nice tablet.  Easy to use with w very responsive screen.  Sure, the internal memory is not the biggest and much of the 'bloatware' cannot be moved to an inserted SD card.  BUT, most of the 'bloatware' can be disabled and this will aid faster performance.  Around 90% of the apps that I have downloaded CAN be moved to the inserted SD card, thus leaving plenty of space on the internal storage.  Around 4gb of the 8gb internal is used up but the remaining 4gb is more than adequate for me.
Sound is sufficient from the mono internal speaker but when earphones are used the sound is really quite good quality.  Camera is only 3mp but again this is sharp and more than adequate for 'snapping' and videos.  Nobody can realistically expect semi-pro shots from a tiny lens and sensor.  Having the front facing low res camera makes Skype easy too.

This is my first mobile computing personal assitant device.  I was biased for the Samsung brand because they had made a great external CD drive.  I have an older Nokia phone which I love but don't use on-line, and it's not useful for apps because its operating system isn't one of the main ones.  I mainkly wanted a mobile device which can run an app which only works on Android, Apple (iOS) or Kindle.  I'm convinced that this is the best entry-level device --- that is, for someone like me who is accustomed to a desktop keybard and cell phone, and new to tablets and touch-screen.  The size is perfect for carrying around --- big enough to get some useful internet use, more than with a cell phone-size device, and small ehough for a purse, brief-case, man-bag, etc.  I am keeping mine inside a quart-size polyethelene food storage bag.  I made the fit a little tighter with some tape, so that this both protects it all around, including the screen, and is transparent so that I can use the tablet inside this cover --- it acts as a screen protector.
F*!k Samsung

i love my Galaxy Tab 4!  I am coming from a Motorola Xoom 10 inch tablet and don't miss the size at all.  I love the smaller, handier size of a 7 inch tablet.  Games, apps, even browsing is fast and smooth.  i also have a Samsung Galaxy 4 phone so using the tablet is just about identical, making it even easier to become accustomed to.  Love love love!

The Tab 4 is more of a budget style tablet than some of the other Tablet offerings out there by Samsung and their competitors.  It all depends on what you would like to use it for to justify getting this tablet.  The overall tablet form is good and still runs on Android 4.4.4 kitkat.  It comes with your typical samsung/android fair of apps and settings, but these can all be adjusted to whatever design you wish to choose(which is why I prefer android devices).

My main reason for purchasing this tablet was for work purposes.  It's easier to use and organize notes and other aspects of daily work life.  In addition when I am home it has a nice enough screen to watch things such as netflix, and other viewing apps.

I found no issues in the casual use of it.  However, there are only 2 things that I wasn't fond of.  The first is the screen is not gorilla glass so it's more prone to get scratches(I bought a screen protector to try and prevent this).  Another item I found, at least for my tastes, is that the speaker on the unit was not as powerful as I wished it to be.  Then again this could be the reason it's more price effective, and if you are only going to use headphones, then it would be perfectly fine.

PROs:

Great Price
Screen Size
Decent Display

CONs:

Speaker
Screen Not Gorilla Glass

All in all, I didn't have any issues with the general use of the device, and it works well for what I intended.  Depending on what kind of use you want out of your tablet it could very well suit your needs.  The bright side of it not costing $500-$700 is you can be a little more carefree with it instead of having to take great care to prevent having anything happen to it.

The screen is bright and the colors are vivid. I am able to use a 64 GB sd micro card with no trouble even though this tablet is only supposed to use up to 32 GB. You get about 4.7 GB of internal storage, but between phone and internal storage, you really get 8+ GB for applications. I am able to move applications to internal storage to use the internal storage too, something that I couldn't do with newer versions of cyanogenmode on my old tablet. I am able to remote-control it from my computer using Team Viewer. There could be more memory. Even though 1.29 GB looks like a lot, the OS, built-in applications and installed applications use it up. If I really scrub the memory, I can free up about 500 - 700 MB of the memory, but it quickly goes down from there. The bluetooth audio works great until it loses its connection after the tablet has been asleep for a while. The pairing is still there, but it has to be reconnected. The best cover I have found is the Barnes and Noble cover for their Samsung Nook, which is the same device, just with a custom, simpler interface. I like this Samsung's interface well enough that I don't want to root it. It has plenty of functionality, though it doesn't have the sheer number of setting found in cyanogenmod. I am not quite proficient with closing the split screen, but it is nice when you want to look at two applications at once. The default keyboard is sized for a phone, not a tablet, so it is quite small. The wireless-N connectivity is pretty fast, but it won't necessarily use the full amount of throughput that you get from your internet connection. I have 200 Mbps downstream and my tablet reaches over 60 mbps. I know that devices hooked up to wireless like my laptop can go at the full speed, but the tablet's speed is quite respectable. The camera is not the best quality, but I have heard that the default android camera software is old and not the best, so it might not be the hardware. I read that a lot of android phones have very good cameras but the software keeps the camera from its full potential.

After 2 weeks of attempting to get my Samsung Tab 3 warrantied I am told tonight by Willy in Consumer Relations that "there is nothing Samsung can do to repair my tablet", incessantly sighting Physical damage as the cause.  The tablet was working fine and charging correctly at night, in the morning it would not turn on or charge. I took two pictures of the charging port showing there was no physical damage prior to shipping it to the repair center, as I was expecting to be brushed off citing physical damage, as is common with consumer electronics. When I asked to speak to someone else, I was told "there was no one else to speak with" which I find hard to believe that Willy is solely handling all of the Samsung inbound calls on his own. This little tablet is great, if you know what you're getting. The driving factor that lead me to getting this device was Web browsing. I wanted something bigger than my phone (LG Optimus G Pro), and something more convient for times when I don't want to break out my MacBook Pro. I debated, and almost bought 8 inch version, I'm glad didn't. This is just the perfect size for me. I can browse online and comfortably view any website in landscape mode, while a quick flip to  portrait mode makes typing a breeze. I downloaded Big Hero 6 from the play store to check out the video quality and was impressed, but not overwhelmed. Granted I did buy the SD version, opting to save a few bucks over the HD version which would certainly look better. The speaker is "okay" but certainly gets the job done. I recommend headphones when your outside the confindments of a quiet room. Besides the guy sitting five away at Starbucks probably isn't interested in hearing the YouTube video you're watching. What I find to be the most impressive aspect of this device is the battery life. I've run the device for two days on a single charge with moderate+ use. This includes updating software,  downloading apps, browsing, watching downloaded videos, and streaming YouTube. I almost passed on this device to go for something with better specs. I'm glad I didn't however, as this does what I want on budget friendly slate. I would have given five stars instead of four if not for bloatware (which I understand comes with every device, even iOS devices). There's just two many Samsung apps that I'll never use or be able to get rid of. Thankfully this device has expandable storage to make up for the space the usless apps take up.

This tablet is not very fast.  I have a Note 3 that runs laps around this thing.  I have never owned a tablet before (well I had a Nabi 2 for my daughter before this) and I guess I thought that the Tab 4 would run as well as my Note 3.  I, admittedly, was a bit uneducated on it all and I assumed that although my phone runs at a ~2.3 ghz processing speed (quad core) that this tablet's ~1.2GHz (quad core) would run similar since it has less to run (i.e., no PHONE parts - no need for a SIM card or that software, idk.  I guess I shouldn't assume I know anything about technology lol).  This tablet is sluggish.  But really I bought it for my 4 year old, so it is okay for what it is used for.  But I will not be using it in any of my college classes and I do my internet shopping on my Note 3, because everything is faster.

2.  "KIDS MODE"

If you bought this for the "Kids Mode," the first thing you might notice is that Kids mode does not come installed.  It is confusing, because if you look in your list of "all applications" (under settings), you can see the application there (with a dinosaur icon).  However no icon on any of the home screens on the tablet itself or under installed applications.  I did a hard reset and still it did not pop up, as I read online that some people were able to do a hard reset and the app icon popped up after that.  This did not work.  After some more goofing around and internet research I realized that you have to go under the "widgets tab" in the app drawer, and scroll through the list of widgets and it is there (although if you don't update the software first, it might not even be in widgets yet).  When you long press the widget to get it to the desktop it just looks like an icon.  It does not look like you would expect a widget to.  From there you load it.

I like the "kids mode" app itself, except you can only have a LIMITED number of apps.  I was hoping to just load every single app my kid has ever liked to play in there for her but I had to pick and choose.  Also, if your kid button smashes and hits the power button, they can get out of kids mode accidentally.  This is problematic because of what I will mention in 3.

3.  Multiple User Profiles

This software allowing multiple user profiles is kind of neat.  However, there are some annoying things about it.  For example, you can ONLY run "kids mode" from the "owner" user profile.  Because of this, if your kid does what I mentioned in 2. above and gets out of kids mode accidentally (normally when you hit "exit" properly, the parent has to enter a 4 digit pin to actually exit), they end up in your profile and can navigate wherever they want to.

Other annoying things about the way multiple user profiles work:

- You can't lock someone out of the Google bloatware, such as the google search bar, etc.

- You can't share pictures from one user to another in the gallery.  Samsung tech tells me this is a "security risk" for the owner of the tablet.  SO, if you are going to use this table for a "RESTRICTED user" (i.e., an older child who would not want to use "kids mode"), and you want to set a wallpaper/lockscreen to a picture, you have to install some sort of photo sharing app (like This Life by Shutterfly, or I think you can download Dropbox), load the picture to the app, and then pull it from there into the restricted profile.  But you have to load the app of course from the "owner" profile (which is kid of tedious), then uninstall it if you don't want your kid messing around in dropbox anymore.  Unless you run a launcher (like Nova) and hide the app from within their profile, but that is getting pretty complicated, and it is suggested that the tablet's native Touchwiz launcher works best if you're using multiple user profiles.

- You cannot run Kids Mode from within a restricted profile.  This is what I was hoping to do with the tablet.  Have my daughter's own icon that she could click on, then she'd launch her user and select the only icon I would have available for her - "Kids mode" (until she gets a little older anyway). Samsung tech support tells me that there is no workaround for this because it would be a security risk to allow multiple users to run the app.  I'm not sure how that is a security risk if you just allow the app to run off a shortcut of the icon in the "owner" profile, which you need a password to make any changes to anyway.  It seems like they could make it so that you can launch a shortcut of the app in a restricted profile or make it so that you can only make changes from the user profile to the kids mode app itself.  I'm sure that would not be that hard of a software tweak to make, but it is a "security risk."

4.  Asthetics

-  You cannot change the color of the menus that I have been able to figure out.  This is nitpicky, but the blasting orange/blue on white background is pretty ugly to look at.  On my Note 3 I can change the background to black.  IDK why you don't have this option on the tablet.  I assumed little things like this would be fluid from device to device, which is why I blindly chose a Samsung tablet to purchase for my daughter.

-  It feels a little more like using an Apple device with the limited amount of options they provide you with in the settings wheel.  Also, you cannot choose to view all the settings options in a list, you have to use their swipe "tab" system.  I don't really find these easier to use and I think it slows down the tablet swiping from tab to tab.  There is a 2 second delay before the tablet fully loads the next setting tab, which is very annoying.  I have reset the tablet twice hoping that somehow this would run smoother, but I have not had any luck.

-  You cannot resize the widgets to a size of your choice in the Touchwiz launcher.  If you use the galaxy apps widget or the weather widget which are automatically available in the widget tab within the app drawer, it takes up like half the screen!

5.  Other things to mention...

- Developer options are accessed by hitting the device serial # 6 or 7 times.  This is just more of an FYI for anyone who wants to know.

-  This tablet doesn't sense my 68 year old mother's fingers!  For some reason her hands can register my Note 3's touchscreen, but not the Tab 4's.  You might want to take that into consideration if you're buying this for someone old with poor circulation.

Overall, this tablet is decent for someone with more patience than me.  I think it is slow and would just pay more for a faster tablet next time.  It is no fun to shop on and if you are running apps that load a lot of info (like amazon store), the app crashes.  I had a Nabi 2 previously for my daughter which had a 1.3 GHz processor that seemed WAY faster.  I also liked the way the kids mode worked much better on the nabi and the way the parent/kid modes split.  You could also automatically launch the nabi in kids mode OR parent's mode, which, to my knowledge, you cannot set the Tab 4 to automatically load into the restricted user profile (which would be dumb anyway I guess since you can't have your kid use the Kids Mode in their own profile - which still makes no sense to me).  This tablet comes with almost no bloatware, which is nice.  If I could go back again, I'd get a more expensive tablet with a faster processor I guess (although the Nabi 2 runs at about the same so I'm not sure why the Tab 4 is so slow).

My husband gave me the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 7.0" for Christmas.  He purchased it at Best Buy and it came bundled with a very nice Belkin case (in black) and a 16GB SD card.  Not having very good WiFi access, I have mainly been using this as an e-reader, using the Kindle App.  I have a Kindle Touch, which I love, but our temporary living quarters does not have very good lighting, making it difficult to read my Kindle in the evening or at bedtime.

Compared to the Kindle Touch, the Tab 4 is close in size.  The Tab is longer and the Touch is wider.  Weight-wise they are close with the Tab (maybe) being slightly heavier.  The screen on the Tab is larger, which for me, is not necessarily a plus.  The Touch has the nice edges around the screen, which make it easier and more comfortable to hold in one hand while reading.  The Belkin case helps a little but I have purchased an additional case that came with a wireless keyboard that offers a good place to grip while reading.  The downside is that it adds weight.

As far as reading in the Kindle App, I'm very pleased.  Of course it does not come nearly as close as the Touch does to reading from the pages of an actual book but it's not as bad as I thought it would be.  It offers options to change the background and text colors.  I find that reading with a black background and white text is easier on the eyes in dim lighting.  The page turning is basically the same.  I actually prefer the Kindle store on my Tab or my phone (Galaxy S4) to the Kindle itself because they show book prices in the list view.  If I'm shopping from my Kindle, I have to go into the book's detailed page to view the price.

As for the other applications on this device, I haven't had much change to try them.  I am typing this review and have written several others using the Tab with the wireless keyboard, which I purchased here on Amazon (NEWSTYLE Removable Wireless Bluetooth Keyboard and Protective Case).  This makes reviewing much easier, since my regular computer is in storage.  When I have better WiFi access I will be excited to try other apps and games.  This seems to be a great little device.  The e-reading capabilities alone are worth the price.

I purchased this tablet for Valentine's Day for my bf and he got to use it for one day before he ran out of memory. He went to Walmart and purchased a new SD card. He then tried to move some games to the SD card and got an error saying "Unable to move to SD card". So we called Samsung support the 2nd day of using this NEW tablet and they did all the troubleshooting they could. They couldn't figure out what the issue was and blamed it on the SD card EVEN THOUGH they had already tested to see if other files/photos could be moved to the SD, which they COULD. So basically Samsung tech support was USELESS and in denial that it was an issue with the actual tablet. So yeah, returning it to Amazon. Looking at iPad minis now.

Update:

After setting up a return, we decided to try the tablet one last time with a different SD card. We WERE able to move some games to THAT SD card, so we switched the SD card again to the first one that we had issues with and we WERE able to move some games into it. It turns out the problem was with certain games. They DID have an option to be moved, yet they did NOT move. We decided to keep the tablet and delete the bad unmovable games instead. I still do wish that Samsung would have caught this, but obviously the tech support needs more training.

If you do end up purchasing this tablet, just be aware that your favorite games may NOT be able to be moved to the SD card even if they have the option that says MOVE TO SD CARD. This becomes a problem because it will fill up the internal memory fast and cause other issues.

First off let me say the screen and finish are very nice.  now the bad stuff:
This 8 gig model has over 4 gigs of unremovable bloatware.

Samsung will not allow you to update the firmware to anythjng newer, or older.
Touchscreen lags so if you are on a page that is updating you will have to wait for several seconds or even minutes before you can press the web link you want.
Very slow at using non samsung apps. Firefox has A LOT  of trouble keeping any memory available. Various cleaner apps like cw cleaner indicate heating and boosting issues. Every five minutes it uses 500mb of ram that need to be flushed before you can get proper usage out of it. Purchased at Costco for 159 and thankfully they will return it with no questions. Samsung cust care is almost non existent.
The keyboard frequently misses inputs and the o and p swap places often. Samsung forums are filled with these issues and the predictive typing is a joke.
Lastly, the wifi issue.  It will constantly lose and rescan the network, even when it shows as connected. The only work around is a temp one, manually adding your network by ssid, then passcode every week Gets very tiring.  Memory hog!

Overall I like this tablet, but I've had a few issues and am exchanging it for another one to give it one more chance.

1) At first the battery life was low, so I had to write to Samsung and they replied with a lengthy email with a lot of links...in the end that seemed to work.

2) When I first fired it up, wifi/internet was very laggy and I was disappointed.  I put it down for the night and when I started it the next morning it downloaded the next version of KitKat OS.  That seemed to help.  Then later in the day it downloaded yet another version,4.4.2.  Weird that it didn't just come with 4.4.2, unless I got a used one (???).

3)  Wifi is weak even one room away.  Ipod touch 4G and Ipad mini are better than this in the sames rooms at the same times. Sometimes wifi stops and I have to turn it off and back on again which seems to fix it.

4) My latest issue is that when I plug the tablet into a home or car stereo, the sound is very low, even with stereo and tablet volume all the way up.  When you do set the tablet volume up, the sound becomes very scratchy like a distant AM radio station.  I looked for internet answers, bought a new cable, tested my Ipod touch on both stereos (which worked fine, with both cables), did a hard factory reset,  and spent 1/2 hour on chat with Samsung.  The chat assistant said it was a tablet/stereo incompatibility.  Highly unlikely since every other tablet/Ipod/Ipad I've run through these systems sounds fine.  Then she said it was bad speakers...again, the radio/mp3/other device sound is fine. At least she tried. She asked if I tried different apps...I had...games, mp3, Google player, etc...all had the issue.  (By the way the headphones work fine at all volumes, as does the bluetooth link for sound to an external speaker).

I am now exchanging it.  If the next one does the same thing, I'll give it a 1 star and get a refund.  If not, I'd give it a 4 star.  It is not super speedy, but I'm not a power user...mostly mp3's, email and internet browsing.  I do wish I could get a 16MB version as the OS uses about 3.5 MB.  Definitely get a 32GB SD card...unfortunately not all apps can be placed on the SD card.

We tried the Fire tablet (ick!) and sent it back while ordering this one instead. This was a present for my 10 year old and it's been really great. We all have Samsung S4 phones and I've been super happy with my Samsung phones the past few years and I also have the Samsung Note tablet 8.0 with the little pen. While my girl does wish the tab had a pen like mine, she actually prefers the smaller shape of the Tab and all in all she's been thrilled (she's had it a few months now...). We've had absolutely no problems with it and unlike the Fire tablet you can access anything you want online including all the google apps you've previously bought through google play (Amazon Fire doesn't let you access the Google Play store in any way shape or form - you'd have to root the device to do it, thus voiding your warrantee). All the Samsung phones and tablets have a super easy to use and navigate interface. It's easily customizable with many available options for static or dynamic wall papers (my favorite is an aquarium that I have on both my tablet and phone) and tons of apps through google play. You can also download the Amazon apps for Android as well, but I've yet to see any on the Amazon store that I can't find on play and I like having all my apps on Google Play so that they're automatically migrated to any new Android product I buy (such as when you upgrade your phone or tablet, or add a new Android device).

I highly recommend this product for kids, teens and any adults looking for a better alternative than the cultish Apple Ipad (I'm sure I'll take some heat for that comment...). It's a great tablet, a great size and well worth the price.

Okay for the money. Excels in many areas, leaves you wanting in many others.
PROS:
* Good value - Nice price point
* Relatively speedy - No lags to speak of
* Expandable - Was able to use a 64GB Micro-SD card (Not limited to 32GB, as per the instructions.)
* Nice, vivid screen
* Battery life is good
CONS:
* Limited memory - The 8GB memory is quite limiting (Even using an external SD card)
* Few sensors - No compass, no light sensor, no gyroscope
* Rear-facing camera is only so-so, fixed-focus.

That said, it's still a nice value, and you won't cry in your pillow that much. if it gets broken, lost, or stolen.

My short review: this is a great tablet for personal use, with one MAJOR disappointment and that is AMAZON PRIME INSTANT VIDEO DOES NOT SUPPORT THIS OR OTHER SAMSUNG TABLETS.

My long review: I've been an Android user for a long time but this is my first Samsung device. I purchased this mostly for my personal use (internet, email, pictures, books magazines, games, light watching, etc.) this is a great tablet and I recommend it for these uses. BUT, I am a parent of preschool/elementary school age kids and I also wanted to be able to access my purchased Amazon library content on it. However, this and apparently other Samsung Tables are not supported by Amazon Prime Instant Video which is a very BIG disappointment and if I was aware of this before I would not have purchased this tablet. I did consider returning it but as I said it works great for my personal use so I will keep it and instead next time I want to buy a movie I'll probably buy on Google Play.

My rant: I have done a lot of research on the web and there are supposedly ways to stream prime videos but I have not been able to get either to work. I did download the Prime app (which was not trivial) but it only directs me to the website which sends me the Amazon app which directs me to the Prime app which sends me to the website again, ... you get the picture. Needless to say, the same app works seamlessly on my HTC phone. There is also an "un-official way" which is a pain to set up (download a separate browser and flash player, change bunch of settings on your device as well as your prime settings, which could mess up your other devices) and even then, you still cannot download your movies to play off-line.

I cannot be sure of this but I believe that this is not necessarily a technology issue but a marketing issue. So AMAZON AND SAMSUNG PLEASE TAKE NOTE because I and 95% of other parents of young children who I know (or who I don't know but have observed in public places) would like to be able to play movies/TV shows for our kids outside of home where there is no wifi. Example: in a restaurant, on a plane, on a road trip, in a hotel room, etc. which means the content need to be ON THE DEVICE AND NOT STREAMING so Netflix and hulu and Amazon Prime on this device are useless.

The 7in. Galaxy Tab 4 is the best all-around tablet I've ever used. I purchased a refurbished model sold here by Ocean Reef Electronics and couldn't be more satisfied with the purchase. I've seriously switched from my iPhone to this tablet. It fits easily into any of my jeans pockets (I wear size 33-32). It's so much easier to use than my iPhone was it's unbelievable. I have fairly large hands, and using this size of device is just so much easier. Couple that with the multi-tasking capabilities and keyboard shortcuts and I've been more "productive" and with less "effort" than with the iphone just had to tailor a few settings to the way I interact with the device (which it seemed like I was constantly doing on the iphone and never being wholly satisfied with it). "Tablet-sized" devices may not be for everyone but for me it just works. This is my first amazon review and I felt compelled to share such a positive experience with a device. I plan to get rid of my iPhone completely and replace it with the most basic talk/text phone to maintain a phone number and mobile text capability, and use Ting(keep reading) for service. I estimate I can shrink my phone bill down to less than $20/month (from the $35ish I was averaging with the iPhone and ting). Check out ting dot com and compare your own bill/usage and see for yourself. Also I applied a Mr. Shield anti-glare screen protector. I highly recommend to my friends and family an anti-glare screen protector for any device.

Never ever ever ever going to buy Samsung products again. The tablet itself was nice, at first. Then after only using it a few times, it started to freeze and the screen had flashing horizontal white bars across it. I spent over 2 hours on their online FAQ section and service area. I performed every restart and reset possible, and it still locks up after only a few minutes of being turned on.

Now, I am sure it is just a defective device, which is fine, it happens. But what I cannot understand is why the person at the other end of the phone in their customer service department almost refused to do anything except tell me to reset the machine or to take it somewhere where a technician can reset it for me... really? I have been using electronics for my entire life, I think I know how to follow a few directions on resetting a device. I was one of those people in the eighties who could set the clock on their VCR properly, so it is a little insulting that they assumed I was completely clueless.

Their products may be fine, but based on the service alone, I will never buy another product of theirs.

I hope this helps others to make a more informed choice when looking for a device. Don't just look at the cost, look at the service. That is why I normally spend a few dollars more on higher-quality products backed up by more responsible parent companies.

I just received my tablet a few days ago and I love it. A lot of people write reviews with specs and comparisons, I just tell you what I like, which is a bit of a comparison to Amazon's own Kindle Fire (2nd Gen.) A while ago I bought an S3 phone and to this day it remains the best phone I have ever owned. That phone made me a Samsung Customer for life. When it came time for me to upgrade my Kindle Fire I almost bought an HDX but at the last moment, I opted for the Galaxy Tab for one simple reason... Google Play. As much as I loved my Fire, the clunky keyboard and inability to get a lot of the apps I love was what ultimately steered me toward the Galaxy Tab and I have not been disappointed. I love the user- friendly interface and I especially love how similar it is to my phone. I haven't yet found an app I wanted that I could not get. As soon as I fired it up and logged into my account it automatically installed everything for me very quickly. All I had to do was remove 2 or 3 apps that were specific to my phone and one that requires the use of a flash or exterior light. The battery has a great lifespan and the charger has a nice, long cord. The screen is beautiful, vibrant, and very responsive. The galaxy tab is also much lighter than my old Kindle Fire making it much easier for me to read into the wee hours of the morning. I will stop short of considering the Galaxy Tab a superior device, after all I am comparing a brand new device to one that I purchased a few years ago, perhaps I would feel different if I were comparing my Galaxy tab to a brand new HDX. So far Amazon's customer service has been TOP NOTCH with my Kindle Fire (actually I have two,) and I think Samsung would be hard pressed to beat them. In the end, as I said before..Google Play and a true android operating system is what won me over.
If you have a Galaxy phone you're in love with and looking to compliment it with a tablet, you cannot go wrong with a Galaxy Tab.

I give this tablet a 5 star for me.  When I first got it, I almost wrote a horrible review.  It was confusing, didn't work like my other tablet running the exact same flavor of Android (which was also a Samsung) and seemed underpowered.

Now that I given the tablet the benefit of the doubt and worked with it for a while...I really like it.  a lot!  The screen is really bright..sometimes too bright.  The processor is not going to make your hair fly back, but I will be lying if I didn't say that it was my own fault for over-loading the memory with multiple apps...that is just the nature of the Android OS right now...only certain apps have permission to put information on the handy external SD card.  So, the internal memory gets full and then slows down the whole thing.
It is a great size for games and reading...but my favorite thing is to have it as my work tablet...I usually carry pages and pages of documents and schedules which all fall out of the binder or the post-it notes fall off the sheets.
With my Tab 4, I upload everything to my Box or Evernote account and have everything with me.  If I have to copy notes quickly or duplicate something, I snap a picture and let one of the apps make it searchable.
I will admit that it has taken me a while to get tablets involved in my work life, but this little guy made it very easy.

If you're looking to buy yourself a cool new toy without breaking the bank, look no further than the Galaxy Tab 4. I have been a long time apple user, and as a matter of fact still have my 1st generation iPhone! I as well have the MacBook pro and the 2nd Gen Ipad mini. So yah I guess you could say I was the poster child of apple. Well, a few weeks ago a family member got me this tablet not knowing that I already had an iPad(It didn't help that I didn't use it much). I happily took it due to the fact they also got me a data plan for it as well! I have never really been able to get into tablets really. For me a phone and a laptop was all I needed.  However, this little guy changed all of that! First off, this is the first time I've used an android device in about 3 years and FINALLY it feels like they have caught up, if not surpassed apple in their software. Yes, of course it feels I bit weird using Android, but I'm learning to love it! Converting over makes you feel like you've broken out of the usual, and gives a feeling of awesomeness customizing every aspect of your experience on this tablet! My friends, if you've been wanting to get your first tablet,  but are a little nervous, or don't know how to "Take the leap" THIS IS THE TABLET FOR YOU! I mean at only a 150$ you really don't have much to lose! Now I will say there are a few things this tablet does lack, however none of it shocks you for how much you have paid for it! First off, you're gonna wanna grab a micro SD card right off the bat. 8 gigs isn't a whole lot and really SD cards are so cheap now a days, it makes you wonder why apple charges you 100$ for 16 gigs more storage? Also, don't plan to make this your go to camera,  while the pictures get the point across, 3 mega pixels isn't enough for this to be your every day shooter. All in all you really feal like you're getting your money's worth with this tablet. It doesn't feel like a high end tablet, but at the same time it does everything you want it to do at a very reasonable price, all while still feeling study to hold, and useful for everything! Plus, if you are like me and didn't know how to break into the wonderful world of android with all its feature, customisation, and "freedom", this is a great way to give it a try and see what you've been missing out on! Or if you're just looking to break into the new and big world of tablets, there's no better place to start than here!

P.s. ever since they announced the iPhone 6 I couldn't wait to get it, but thanks to this tablet I think I'll be switching over to a new Galaxy phone instead!

For $158 (at the time I purchased this), this is a great 7" tablet.  It's not too light, not too heavy, and has a good, solid feel.  Everything I've run on it so far has run really smooth and haven't had any issues thus far.

Pros:
- Fits in my pant's pocket if I need it to
- Micro SD slot
- Has a lot of the common things in most tablets: camera, WiFi, bluetooth, GPS, etc
- Speaker is loud
- Backing feels really good, not slippery
- Android and apps run great and very smooth

Cons:
- Camera could have been better, 3 MP on the rear is a bit lower than what I'd expect out of Samsung.  6-8 MP would have been nice.  Fortunately I don't plan on taking too many pictures with this.
- No camera flash
- Rear facing speaker.  Also when watching a video and using the rear speaker for audio, sometimes you can really hear the audio better in 1 ear than the other.
- No light sensor = no auto brightness option
- Only 8 gigabytes built in storage

To me, all of those cons are only worth the 1 star loss.  This really is a great tablet and I am very satisfied with my purchase.
