Pros for this tablet:
-Form factor means it fits in your hand really well.  I have small hands and I can palm it.
-Screen is actually pretty decent for what you are paying for.  Colors are bright and while a little oversaturated on my unit, they are still pretty good.  Videos look good, blacks are fairly black and whites are white.  The viewing angle is excellent.
-Micro SD slot.
-Battery life is decent for what the device is priced at. I am getting about 5.5 hours or so out of it with normal use.
Cons for this table:
-The biggest issue is the 8GB of on board storage.  With the OS installed there's just over 4GB of space open.  The tablet requires 3.72GB of open space to function properly.  This leaves you with less then 1GB to install apps.  Data from some apps can be moved to an SD cards but apps themselves cannot be.  Basically, there's almost no room to install anything on this tablet if you want it to be usable.
-Speaker is on the rear.  It is not easy to hear even at full volume if you are in an open space.
-It's slow.  Not just poky or a little janky, I'm talking downright slow.  The quad-core CPU and 1.5GB of RAM mean nothing  when apps take forever to load off the slow storage in the device.  Smaller apps like Facebook take longer to load then even my 4 year old iPad 2.  Games, if you can get them to install on the tiny storage, have long load times and are full of graphical glitches because of the slow, small storage.
-The Version of the Android OS that it was supposed to come with is 4.4.4.  Mine had 4.4.2 installed and refuses to find the 4.4.4 update via the software update service.  The Samsung Keis software finds the update but it won't install.  I wound up resetting the device and clearing all my installed apps and it still won't install.  It isn't that big of a deal,  but still, it should have came with what it said on the label.  The Android 5.0 upgrade is supposed to be coming for the device but I'm not holding my breath.

What it comes down to is that this is a small, cheap device that's handicapped by the slow, measly amount of storage on board.  Don't buy this tablet.  If you want an inexpensive tablet, pick up an Asus Memo Pad 7 or better yet, a Nexus 7.  Get at least 16GB of storage or more.

I ordered this tablet after some bad luck with other tablets. I had the Fire HDX and absolutely loved it but it would constantly restart and I just got too frustrated dealing with that so traded it in. The next tablet I tried was the Acer Iconia 8 and that had a touch screen that was not at all responsive. By the time I got my Galaxy I was over the whole tablet issue! When I got this tablet though I was immediately pleased. I should disclose that I have a Samsung Galaxy S4 already so I loved the fact that the Galaxy Tab was so similar. I immediately had all of the settings, etc exactly how I'm used to them. I was a little disappointed in the display. Going from an HDX to the lower resolution Tab was a bit disappointing, but really for what I use it for it's fine. The speed is pretty good, I did upgrade my storage immediately with an SD card (love that this is option) so I basically tripled my storage for $15. The camera is pretty mediocre. I'd rather take pictures with my phone, but I didn't buy the tablet to take photos. I use my tablet for web browsing, reading on the Kindle App and answering e-mails and texts. For this purpose it's perfect and for the money it's an unbelievable deal. Not to mention you get all of the access that Google Play and Samsung provide. I recommend.

This is a great tablet for the price, and has expandable storage available through the micro SD slot. I have my Tab 4 7.0in running with a Samsung  Evo 32GB card, and it works flawlessly. The response time and accuracy on this tablet seems to be much better than my and older Tab 3.0. I am not sure why Samsung list this as only 32GB expandable for Tab 4 7.0 and Tab 4 8.0. I tested it with my 64GB from my Galaxy S3 and it worked. I have even heard that some people have been able to get 128GB cards to work.

With the 7 in screen its size is smaller than the iPad Mini, the 8 in Tab 4 model screen size is about the same as the iPad. However, from my research the Tab 4 8" and Tab 4 7" models have identical processors and internals (the 8" model does have a larger battery 4450mAh vs 4000mAh), and since this was for my daughter I didn't see the need for +$90 for the slightly larger screen. I was trying to find a decent smaller size tablet without breaking the bank. The new iPad mini 16 GB is $300 and 64GB is $500!! This Galaxy Tab 4 7" was on sale new for $130, a 32 GB card was $20, giving me 40GB total memory for $150. This gives me over double the storage capacity, for half the price. In my opinion I prefer the Android OS anyway, due to its better compatibility across different media types and sources.

I would recommend this tablet to anyone looking for a small quality Android tablet.

I bought this tablet for me son as an inexpensive emulator device.  He enjoys playing NES, SNES, and other retro games.  The 4.4 android OS does not support using external bluetooth console controllers, so my original idea of pairing my Wiimotes or PS3 controllers with it was no good.  There is no current solution or workaround.  My next idea was to pair up the PS3 remote via USB OTG...alas, the hardware does not support OTG cables (which also nerfs any idea of plugging in an external storage device.)  So, I bought an iPega bluetooth controller which actually works really well with this tablet...but when I tried to plug it into the TV for mirroring, no-go.  It does not support MHL for the micro-SD to HDMI interface.

This is a great tablet for browsing the internet or reading books...but the lack of power and losing all of the hardware options available in the 10" model makes it a hard sell.

My wife is really enjoying the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4...great screen resolution, good sound, takes great pictures & video, and works well overall (she has a Samsung Galaxy 5 Active phone which she is also enjoying). Only drawback with the purchase was the length of time it took to finally arrive...4 days from California to Dallas (no problem), then 4 days "vacationing" in the Dallas Metroplex  (problem). Then took 2 more days to arrive here from the Dallas area (185 miles). It makes one wonder why it took less time to travel 1,200 miles than it did 185 miles.  Tracking & estimated date of delivery were way off...my 1st time ever having this problem with Amazon purchases.  Hence, no 5-star rating on this purchase.  I would definitely buy these items again, but would not hold my breath for on-time delivery.

Liked the tablet, size, and android system.  The problem was I didn't have sound.  Spent almost an hour and a half on Christmas day with Samsung support, they were very nice and helpful, but could not fix the problem.  By fooling with settings, volume control and using a trick I found on line, sometimes I could get sound on Netflix, it was very low and if I changed screens or movie, I would lose it again.  Finally they told me the tablet had a problem and return it for repairs, however, they said since it was only 2 days old, to return it to Amazon,  Amazon was great, downloaded shipping label, reboxed it, took to UPS the next day, had my payment refunded to my credit card the next day.  Since I like the tablet and the price, except for lack of sound, I am going to purchase another one and hopefully it won't have a problem with the sound.

I rate this tablet with a 2 star rating for mainly one reason. I bought this tablet for my mother for christmas, she unwrapped it today so she could start using it. The Tab 4 7.0 is a decent mini tablet for the price, however I was still left slightly unimpressed.  The processor is quick enough but nothing to write home about.  The same can be said for the screen, which is big enough to enjoyably watch Netflix but the resolution still leaves something to be desired.  The storage capacity is on the lower end and you will probably need an SD card which must be limited to 32gb.  I feel like the battery life could also be better.  The construction isn't particularly reassuring and the cheap looking fake chrome plastic bezel is just terrible/lazy design.  The "camera" was probably a surplus part from a phone made in 2006 and is disappointing, lackluster, and something you won't use.

Despite my long list of flaws, for the price this is definitely an acceptable entry-level tablet or e-reader.  I do like the Tab 4 7.0 for what it is.  However, you can't help wonder what they could have made if they didn't cut corners and I probably would NOT buy this again.  I would buy the 8" model with better performance.

I bought this just as a cheapy tablet to use for watching movies and light internet browsing.  I currently have an s5 phone so I figured this would be perfect to use when traveling.  I do like the tablet, but it does have some bloatware and limited internal space.  I would not recommend for someone who wants to install a lot of apps and games as you will run out of space.  I did install a sd card that I use to put videos on from my playlater account.  If you don't know what playlater is you should google it and purchase it so you can record videos to your sd card.

Anyways back to reviewing this table.  The screen is really good and makes for a great video player!  However samsung thinks its a good idea to put the speaker on the back.  The speaker on this sounds clear but even on the maximum volume setting it can be hard to hear.  Build quality is good and its very light to hold.  The camera sucks on it (not sure why they even have one) and battery life is pretty good.  I wish the back key and app key would light up like they do on the phones.  I also wish it had touch feedback when using the back key or keyboard (the little vibration the galaxy s5 makes when touching the keys).

If you need a cheap tablet to use for movies and internet browsing this is perfect, if you want lots of games and apps look for a tablet with at least 32gig internal storage.

I'm almost entirely satisfied with this product. Its my first tablet and I really like it except for a few faults. After a couple weeks I noticed there was a little black spot underneath the glass. It's about the size of a single pixel, but its not a dead pixel; it looks like a piece of lint contaminated the clean room during the lamination proces and got stuck below the glass. It's not a big deal, but once I noticed it, I can't unnotice it. Another issue is the proprietary Samsung software is irritating. I know that's kind of subjective, but I suspect many folks will have similar hang-ups. I'm not sure if this is Google's fault or Samsungs, but Google Now doesn't seem to work properly with Google Hangouts (google voice.) on the bright side, the specs stated that this tablet only supports a 32 gigabyte external memory card, but I threw a 64 gigabyte card in there and it works properly.

Update: About two months after purchase, the Samsung power adapter stopped working. At first I was worried the tablet was broken. The charging icon had a blinking lightning bolt on it and the tablet was refusing to charge. After trying various power adapters and cables I have certainly narrowed it down to the power adapter that shipped with this tablet as being the problem. Not a significant issue, but it is indeed tacky. It doesn't yet change my 4-star rating of this tablet.

Bought it the last week of August. By Oct, I was having problems with it freezing up, not being able to access my wireless system, delayed response to touch...and I could go on. Now the thing doesn't work at all. It's frozen. It won't turn off. The volume is non-responsive. Completely broken. Amazon return policy won't allow for return. Love Samsung. Will not buy another tablet from them though. So I spent $180 on a tablet that lasted less than 4 months. Outrageous. Very disappointed.

Honestly I'm a bit disappointed. I've used and didn't care for an iphone/ipad. I currently have 2 Windows 8 phones in my house and love the operating system on a mobile platform (wouldn't touch it on a home PC of course!).  I hadn't used any Androids before and figured I should at least try one out before buying a Windows tablet and becoming a Microsoft fangirl for life. I've used it for a week and a half now to give myself some time to get used to it, my son has as well.

To start, the operating system is laggy. I have fairly cheap Windows phones, not even the newest or best ones. I'm not used to lightning fast or jaw-dropping speed of performance. But this tablet is frustratingly skippy and laggy when opening or switching between things. Nothing closes unless I click multiple buttons to get there to close it.. which is also annoying. I feel like I spend more time opening and closing things than I do using them. If I don't close them, well it's even more laggy.

The layout is not intuitive. After a week and a half I still feel like I'm hunting for everything other than the apps on the main screen, and each task I perform on it is excessively complicated to do. I am pretty technologically savvy, this thing is just bass ackwards on a few things.

Yes, it has a better selection of apps than my Windows phone. Unfortunately I don't need the 10 zillion apps it has that my Windows phone doesn't. Okay, I admit having Candy Crush somewhere other than Facebook finally is nice. But Candy Crush alone does not a tablet make.

The size and weight is nice, the picture clarity is nice. They're not any more nice than any other comparable tablet would have been. The volume and quality of the speaker is truely awful compared to my phone, and my phone's isn't that great. I'm sure it'd sound better with headphones... I hope.

I have given it a fair chance and will continue to use it since I've paid for it. But I won't buy another in the future unless I suddenly discover the "make everything better" button hiding in my apps. My 14 year old son also told me to "never to buy that crap again".  I just do not understand how Apple and Google have the lions share of the market when it comes to mobile devices. I can only assume the Android users have never tried a newer Windows phone/tablet.

Even the two star rating is a bit generous. Like most people, my hopes were clearly too high. What this device's suggested capabilities are compared to it's price point make it a very enticing purchase. Let's start with the pros.

1. It's inexpensive, feels like a small risk.

2. It's size and weight are ideal. I can fit it in the back pocket of my jeans which may not seem like a big deal, but that's truly portable to me. It weighs next to nothing, and makes the Kindle Fire HDX 7" feel like a million tons. You can use easily with one hand over a long period of time with no hand or arm fatigue.

3. I'm a fan of Android OS, so that's a plus to me. Being a fairly dedicated google user makes it an ideal tablet.

4. Expandable memory, many tablets surprisingly don't offer that as an option which makes them useless to me, unless it's a 32gb or larger device. The specs say it can take up to a 32gb micro sd, but I can verify that it will handle a 64gb card without issue.

Now the cons.

1. The small bezel can be annoying at times. I feel I am a fairly average human man at 6'0 tall and 190lbs, but routinely my thumb will open an app or click on something accidentally because there is literally no room to rest your thumb on the device while holding it in one hand. By contrast, the Kindle HDX 7" has about a half inch bezel so your thumb rests easily without touching anything on the screen. But to be fair, the HDX weighs as much as a collapsed star so it is not very easy to hold in one hand for longer durations.

2. The most glaring and annoying flaw by far is the WiFi connectivity of this device. It fails to connect so often that it renders using it almost pointless. I have a gigabit router that fuels every device in my home flawlessly. The samsung drops the WiFi connection every few minutes. I opted to test it on different networks (at my brother's house, and at my parent's house) and the same thing happened repeatedly. It's a clear flaw in the build of this device. After a simple Google search, I found way too many forums dedicated to the inability of the Samsung galaxy tab 4 to connect to WiFi effectively.

In short, at $125 lightning deal I couldn't resist buying it, and I've regretted it every day since I first received it. Buy a Kindle HDX, if you don't require tons of memory then buy the new Fire HD 16gb or the Google Nexus 16gb. Clearly superior devices.

The tablet is awesome in every way except one, storage. The tab only comes with 8 gigs of storage and almost half of it is used by all the bloteware Samsung preinstall on it with no way to remove it unless you root the tab which can be quite difficult on a Samsung device. By time you add the basics apps your tablet will be out of memory. The tab does have a external SD card slot but Samsung won't let you install programs on it. A matter of fact it won't even let you write or save to the SD card without special programs for rooted users. For people who can root their phones there are apps like folder mount that will force the tab to transfer data to SD card, however its a bit complicated and the apps don't always work. Overall this would be an excellent tablet if it allowed the use of an external SD card for storage.

How am I supposed to tell him "sorry your tablet has a dead pixel at the top we have to send it back and you'll be without your awesome new birthday present for a few days" without breaking his heart? So the dead pixel stays. I expect better from a major player like Samsung. It could be worse though. I could've got the Fire Kids Edition for him....

I also don't like how what should be the menu key is a recent key. However some might find that to be a plus.

The audio controls don't rotate with the screen so if you're watching or playing something and the audio controls are at the top you have to hit the left button to turn it up and right to turn it down. Counter intuitive.

Minus the dead pixel the screen is rather fantastic. The micro SD card slot is easy to use, just the press of a fingernail locks it in and pops it out. Front and rear facing cameras is a plus, there were some comparable tablets that didn't have a front camera. The speaker is stronger than I expected. Overall I'd still recommend this for anyone wanting a tablet under $200.

This was a gift. It is my first tablet -- also, I don't own a smart phone, so I have very little experience with hand held devices. (and I'm OLD. How many strikes do I need against me?)

As far as construction, the Tab-4-7" looks very well made. Camera is pretty low rez. which is probably ok for the web.

But IMHO, the Android software SUCKS BIG TIME!  I find navigation very difficult. Chrome is a so-so browser. Android is constantly trying to download software to the tablet.-- I have to shut if off to get it to stop. It seems to me, that Google's Android OS is merely a vehicle for Advertisements. The "free" stuff that comes with the Tablet requires you to give up credit card numbers plus lots of personal information before you can get "free books", "free TV", "free DropBox", etc, etc.
  Oh, and the kicker: I tried to download the Manual onto the Tablet and Samsung tells me that they don't have a manual in my language! (Well, ok, it doesn't speak valley-girl....What Ever!)

I assume I'll be able to transfer music from my Mac, but haven't tried yet.  It would be nice if one could Skype or FaceTime with this, but I don't know if that's possible. It's WiFi only.

I've thought that having a Tablet (or smartphone) would be nice -- possibly a replacement for carrying around my laptop. But after getting this, I don't think so. In fact, I'm not sure what the point of one is, unless it's to provide Big Brother Corporation with all your personal data.
  On the  Plus side; If I put up with the ads, I can play Angry Birds!

With the ipad minis, all apps, music, and over all functionality must be done a certain way. With the Tab 4 I get speed, the option to add a memory card, and when I plug it into the computer it responds as any other drive. I can drag and drop movies, music, pictures and much more into whatever folder I want to. The screen is absolutely beautiful and the size is just perfect. Very small bezel on each side so holding the tab 4 seems much more comfortable than our ipad minis at school. The ipad mini is too wide to feel comfortable. On my tab 4 I listen to music, watch netflix, watch my own movies, view my photos, and of course to browse the web. I also use it for all my productivity needs like my calendar, my task manager, evernote, and documents using Google docs and WPS documents. I've paired it with my Stowaway bluetooth foldable keyboard and I take notes at meetings just as I would a laptop. I keep everything on my google drive so I always have access to it. Hey, I get it. It's a Galaxy and it "SHOULD" be just as great as their cell phones. I have owned a Galaxy S3 for a couple of years and it has NEVER failed me and it's a dynamite product. But a tablet is NOT a phone.

Y'see, I own a Kindle Fire HD. It's a great product and I have had NO issues with it, but I hate the restrictions to the Google Store that it imposes on you. So, I decided to shop for a tablet that doesn't have these restrictions. I settled on the Galaxy Tab. Well, I was NOT impressed with it's performance. My 2-year-old Kindle HD 7 Fire out performs it. Here are some of the things that forced me to return this product:

1. The real estate on the web browsers was an annoyance. I couldn't invoke the FULL-SCREEN mode on any of the browsers that I downloaded. Even though the SETTINGS for that feature was checked.

2. The tiny, tiny, itty bitty, speaker. I was so used to the two-speaker stereo sound that my Kindle Fire HD had, that listening to music or watching Netflix was not enjoyable.

3. The storage issue!! Daily I received the OUT OF STORAGE SPACE alert even though I had a 32 GB external SD Card installed. I was forced to CLEAR the cache on the thing daily just to avoid those annoying alerts.

4. The performance of the web browsers. I'm a GEOCACHER and I like to use my tablet to display maps. This tablet's browsers would hang and lag and just get on my nerves whenever I tried to enlarge or scroll. Kindle's browsers never gave me that problem.

Those are the reasons I decided to continue my search for a non-Google Store-restricted tablet.

This is a good tablet no doubt about it, but to me, It Does not live up to Samsung standards. Let me start by informing you my tech level is a standard nerd that knows must things tech. The IR blaster for TV use does not work and uses a different version of the standard "watch on" app that has less tv and other device brands than the normal "Watch On" app on my note 3. Let alone again never could get it working. The battery life is great. The gps is great as well (I use a stand alone navigation app that does not require data). The looks and touch of the screen is of great quality. The camera quality is decent as well. The Bluetooth is a problem. I can get it to connect to my headset but that's it. Can't play music, videos and hear anything so there is no use for the Bluetooth (I even tried using Bluetooth audio apps like mono Bluetooth,  no luck). The headset plug in works only on headsets. You cannot use an audio jack to plug into speakers, car audio, or anything else besides headsets. You can connect the audio jack from the tablet to speakers but it will only screech and blow out your speakers. The WiFi actually has a fairly long range even though it may say no signal waves in the bar, it will probably still work. I have a 40mb/s isp and get just that on the tablet. Some necessary apps that are common do not work properly such as es file explorer, you can not move files. (Note: I have to use the standard file explorer that came with the tablet which does not let me into system directories.) The battery life is great,  BUT it does have a very picky charging issue. You cannot use any charger. I use the usb cord that came with the tablet, but I learned you cannot use anything that gives more than a 2.1 amp or 2100milli amp output. For some unknown reason the charging ability is outdated by about 8 years. The charger it comes with only pushes 1.2amps which takes about 7 hours to charge the tablet, but I use as I said a 2.1amp charger and it takes about 30 min for a full charge. USING A WRONG TYPE OF CHARGER WILL RESULT IN A RED X OVER THE BATTERY, indicating it is not charging. I typically use a 3.5amp charger for all my devices but can't with this tablet. I have a 32gb mini SD which works perfect and I hold my TV shows and movies as well. BUT the audio on this tablet is very bad and cannot play all new movies such as "The hunger games 2" even though it is in a standard mp4 format as my other movies are that do work such as the new 2014 godzilla and transformers, age of extinction also 2014.
All and all the tablet meets my needs with disappointment. If I would have known all of the issues above I would have bought something else. But this is stuff I slowly figured out as attempting them throughout a month or so expiring my ability to return the device. I still stand by Samsung, but consider the tablet 4 to be a black mark on their rapport. I still use the tablet for my intended needs and will hope for an update to fix the above issues. I was just hoping to use the tablet more than my phone and this tablet has failed at the objective. Again this is a good tablet if the above stuff does not bother you. I have learned to live with it as it does surpass my old tablet abilities by far.

Being a previous owner on many different tablets, I have some initial thoughts about this Samsung Galaxy Tab at first.
- RAM- The amount of RAM on this tablet is very limited. How limited?- 1.5 GB of Memory usage available not considering what the system software uses. I average out freely 800 MB when I'm using low-processing apps. The tablet seems to take a toll when I try to browse on Chrome with several tabs open and play music on Spotify or YouTube in the background. Regardless, for the price you get what you pay for here in this range. Either way, I consider my Nexus 7 (which is only a few dollars more) a more high end tablet.
-Screen- Actually, the screen is really great all HD! One thing is the menu buttons do not illuminate.
-Power- The power consumption is great on this tablet I usually play music and noticed no drainage when it comes to browsing the web and music. Video does drain it considerably.
-Software- I absolutely despise bloatware. Samsung is guilty here of this one. Some of the apps can not be disabled but doesn't take up RAM so in the end I guess we can cope. If you have ever used the Galaxy phones or tabs before you'll be familiar with the user interface.
-Camera- Ehh. 5 and 3 Megapixel. You are better off using your phone but comes in handy.
Overall, its a good starter tablet.

We purchased 2 of these tablets on a special deal at Office Max this fall. Our plans are to use the tablets for homeschool and fun on the go with our elementary school kids (ages 6 and 8).

I have been an iPad2 user for about 3 years, and knew that there would be some differences. The differences go beyond the operating system and branding. Not only do we have some privacy concerns, but we also wish someone had given a better explanation of how you ARE limited to the internal storage capacity of the device. The removable storage does not support apps or software installation (read last part of this review). We have had these tablets for less than a month, and we are already being forced to delete apps. THE DEVICE IS FULL !!! (we have 16 GB micro-SD card installed, and it still has over 13 GB free, but we can not install even one more app)

What we like:
Very lightweight & portable
Perfect size for small hands
Easy to find cases and accessories - be sure get the screen protector from Armor Suit!
The screen resolution and graphics are amazing
The camera is easy to use & takes great pictures
The tablet is a great value
It works great as a TV remote control, and you can view some apps and online videos on your TV using this device

Some differences we noticed right away:
There are built-in "features" that are too invasive for family use, in my opinion:

- If you enter your pattern passcode incorrectly more than twice, the tablet takes your picture and emails it to your registered email account. I can see that this is a great security feature when you lose the tablet, but I found it disquieting, to be receiving multiple pictures of myself and my young children, several times a day. The tablet is taking pictures of you, without your realizing it... There is no way to turn this off. The only solution we have found, is to put a small sticker over the front-facing camera. (I realize that we are being recorded everywhere we go. My husband works for a company that helps manage this new phenomenon of information overload. I would like to restrict outside access to what happens inside my home, as much as I am able... There is really no need for Google (or whoever it is) to be taking pictures of us all day.)
- The "smart screen" that has to sense your eyes, in order to keep the screen running: If you are looking at the tablet, the screen remains active. If you look away or set the tablet down, it turns off within 30 seconds, requiring you to unlock it again to use it. Since we have covered the camera, to avoid our pictures being added to the big database in the sky over and over again each day, our tablets will shut off if we stop touching them for more than 30 seconds.
- You can turn off this "power-saving" feature in the settings menu, but it does not actually change the setting. Each time I have tried to change the setting from 30 seconds to 2 minutes, it resets within 5 minutes, even with continued use. VERY irritating!! How productive can you be, if you have to keep unlocking your tablet while you are working on something??
- When my daughter turned on her Galaxy Tab, it automatically installed all the apps that are on my tracfone, and all of my Google contacts were also in her tablet (which included everyone who had ever sent or received an email from that email address).
- MANY and I mean MOST of the apps that we have installed ask for ridiculous access and require "permissions" to access your information, including your complete network information, your Wifi connection and anything that is attached to it, your contact, access to your phone calls, ability to make and receive calls and text messages, access and delete information on your USB storage... and prevent your device from sleeping (this has drained the battery dry more than once). I don't understand why a Garifled game app would need access to my complete network and identity information.

The biggest realization came yesterday, after about 45 minutes of online chat support through Samsung's website (he was either very bad at typing, or was completely unfamiliar with the technology and specifications). You ARE limited by the internal storage capacity of this device.
- When we purchased these tablets, we were "sold" on the idea that you could upgrade your storage capacity - "Unlike the iPad! You can upgrade your memory capacity!" The tablets even came with a free micro-SD card with a 16 GB capacity - doubling the storage of the tablet, right out the door! What a GREAT idea!
THIS STATEMENT IS NOT COMPLETELY ACCURATE. There is a difference between internal and removable storage, and what it can do. You can NOT install apps to a removable disk. Since we have downloaded several apps and games for kids, our device is already giving us error messages about "insufficient space." After 3 weeks of use, I am forced to delete apps from the device... games and apps that the kids still want to play and use...

If you are someone who likes to use educational or game apps for kids, be informed before the salesman tells you what a GREAT deal you are getting on this type of setup. A Best Buy employee recently tried to talk me OUT of buying a new $800 iPad Air, and moving to a Samsung. He showed me the cost savings, and told me that with the iPad, you are paying extra "for the name." NOT TRUE!!

Google will get into your private business as much as it can, and you will be forced to give it permission to access your entire network and identity, when you download their Android apps. They will take photos of you, whenever they choose. The "upgrades" in storage (via the SD memory) are only useful for pictures, videos, music, and other data you add.

I think this tablet would be great for someone who does not want to install very many apps. If you want to use it to create documents and take notes, it will probably work great. We had intended to install Microsoft Office 365 on these, but I have yet to see how much space that software will consume. We are going to be forced to delete several of our apps.

The external storage will be useful for storing pictures and videos. Kids love taking pictures and videos!
Too bad we have to sacrifice the productivity and fun potential... but NOW I KNOW.

I hope this information helps someone else. All in all, we are pleased with this purchase... but BE INFORMED before you buy.
Think about what you will use it for, and consider getting a tablet with more internal storage capacity.

Outside of an all-in-one desktop computer, this is my first purchase of this kind of technology.  Even the cell phone I have is a cheap pay as you go phone that I use to check email sometimes.  If memory serves me right, it cost me about $15 at Best Buy about 3 years ago.  So anyhow, I'm a newbie at this sort of thing.  After a few days of using the Tab 4, I think it's great but wish it had a phone included at only a slightly higher price range, say, $50.  I purchased this on a spur of the moment impulse and really it's just to watch videos during lunch break or sometimes during my commute (however, this will be rare as my commute is usually dedicated to reading).  One of the best things about this product is that Samsung has free chat help online.  Please, NEVER get rid of this.  This will keep me a customer for life!  Don't start charging for it and don't cut the service.  Hidden expenses besides the roughly $180 plus tax?  Well, you will need a case.  Mine cost $30 in the store.  Some were even more.  But you can find them at half that online.  But get something solid to keep it protected.  You will also want to get the 32gb SD card.  Some comments online state that the 64gb card will work, too.  I asked Samsung in the chat and was told "no," which doesn't make it true, but it's not in the specs, which state a limit of 32gb.  The learning curve, after some tech help, is kind of quick.  Once you see how some things are done, it starts to get easier figuring out other stuff for yourself.  This morning I set up something called WatchOn.  I thought it was to watch cable on the Tab.  But as I afterward found out, it only converts your Tab 4 into a TV/Cable remote.  Really, they should name the app differently.  WatchOn means something entirely different.  There is an app for reading books.  I don't plan to use it as I own several thousand books and still love the feel of a real book.  One feature I like is a program that reads PDF and Word files.  I have a Word file of over 50 pages listing all my books so when I'm out I don't buy stuff I already have.  But I have to carry around a printed version.  Now I can just open it in the Tab 4.  When I was transferring movie files there was a popup asking me if I wanted to convert the movies as they may not play.  Convert them to what?  I'm not sure.  But I said no and they played just fine.  They are m4v files that I made using handbrake.  There is a camera and a video camera (the camera has a front and rear picture option, one of which the quality is a little better in terms of pixels and image size).  The user manual can be downloaded online and explains a lot more than I can here (it also came with a little booklet that I haven't even looked at yet).  Anyhow, there are a lot of features on this device.  Games, etc.  Right now I don't really want to get involved in these things as I want to stay focused on reading.  But for others, I'm sure you'll find lots of interesting things to keep you occupied.  Oh, one more thing.  I bought this Zagg screen protector.  Waste of time for me.  The directions were lousy and I had to throw it out.  What I found out is this though.  In order not to touch the screen directly I wrapped the skimpy (thin) micro cloth that came with the Zagg screen around my index finger and the Tab 4 worked just fine, reacting to my touch as if it were my finger.  I suppose any eyeglass micro-fiber cloth should work fine, too.  In closing, great product and I hope to get several years of good use out of it.  I will definitely buy again from Samsung if they continue putting out a great product with great online help.

Very good for the price. I currently use an S5 for my main phone so I was used to the Samsung ecosystem. The TAB 7 inch is great and I'll lay out a few pros and cons here.
Pros:
Price is reasonable.
Visually appealing tablet,  it's very simply designed with the iconic samsung look.
Works well on most tasks such as Netflix, reddit, light gaming,  etc.
Touch wiz ui has been scaled down to the basics. You can definitely pick it up and run with it.  Was looking for something a little more basic so it worked well.
Cons:
It is my understanding that you can pick up faster tablets for around the same price such as nexus 7.
Currently this model can't be rooted by towelroot.
Cameras are very basic so don't expect much there. App is quick to open and snap pics though.
Have noticed a bit of lag when several apps are running which can be fixed by closing them.
Even though the tablet is 8gb in size,  you only get around 3 gigs of storage space.  Definitely will want to get an SD card here. The official supported size is up to 32gb but I've heard users mention 64 gig cards work in their tablets.

Overall there are good and bad things about it. While there are faster or fancier options available for you to try,  I like this tablet because of its size, basic features, good battery life, and user interface. It's a great option if you want something simple for simple tasks.

I like Samsung but the Android OS is just plain garbage. Sure you can customize the heck out of Android but it is NOT as user friendly as iOS devices. Simple as that. I shipped mine back to Amazon.

Avoid Android at all costs.

Pros:
- Light weight
- Bright screen

Cons:
- Can't get Amazon Prime on Android devices unless you have an Amazon Fire.
- Touch sensitivity is no where near as smooth as an iDevice. It's annoying slow.
- Sluggish, even when you turn off the animations.
- Lots of incompatible apps despite the Google Play store saying that the device is compatible. (crashes, freezing, etc).
- Slow wifi connectivity.
- NOT Enterprise friendly. Remember that if you plan to do some work on this device.
- Security is a concern and Google's updates are manufacturer and carrier dependent so you have to wait until the latest Android Patch is configured for your device.
- Battery life..there's a known software glitch in Android Kitkat 4.4.2 that causes the battery to drain.

I really wanted this tablet to replace my full size iPad 3, but it turned out to be a total piece of crap. It feels cheap and flimsy and the dimensions are not really ideal for anything. Too small to do serious reading on, too heavy to hold while lying down. The back cover is cheap plastic and has an awful lumpy texture and is just not pleasant to hold. The tablet is light but that is almost negated by how thick it is. The iPad, although heavier, is thinner, more ergonomic, feels a lot less buggy, and just generally works better. I gave the Samsung tablet two stars instead of one because technically it's a working tablet and can run most of the same apps, but the user experience is severely lacking. I don't know if I got a defective model, but I also could not remove an external SD card once I put it in. Normally it should just click in and click out, but the second part didn't work. I mostly need a tablet for extensive PDF reading, and the little details make a big difference. It seems that with the iPad, everything is just slightly but significantly smoother, so that the overall experience is much better. More respnsive touchscreen, better keyboard, everything feels snappier, less crashing, etc.

I have used the original Kindle Fire since it was released. It's in a leather folio case and it's heavy. The Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 is lightweight and unlike my Kindle, it has a camera. Not a very good camera, but for closeups, it's okay. As other reviewers have mentioned, the pictures are fuzzy. I thought I could correct the fuzziness in my photography program but I can't. I will try adjusting the camera settings and see if that helps. I DID NOT buy this tablet to take pictures. I bought it to run a program which is not available for Kindle. I have also downloaded the Amazon Store and purchased apps but keep getting a message that I need to purchase the app. It has nothing to do with Amazon and everything to do with the Google Store that comes installed on the tablet. I need to do more research and change some settings. Tablet clarity, the touch screen and ease of use make this the best choice for me. I have a digital camera for taking pictures.

After owning a cheap $69 tablet, it is a relief to have one that doesn't slow down to the point of barely working after a month. I mostly like this, just didn't like the following in regards to this Samsung Galaxy tab 4 7inch.

USB hosting - this 7 inch tablet doesn't do it. Very disappointed, because the cheapo tablet I owned before did. After doing some internet research, it sounds like only the 8 and 10 inch tablets do this. So now I kind of wish I had bought the tab 3 in the 8 inch version, instead of the tab 4 7 inch.  I really wish I could put pictures from my camera onto the tablet. I like to share pictures this way when I am on vacation. I tried with a USB-OTG cable with no luck. If anyone figures out how to do this, I would love to know.

Amazon instant video - I was holding out on getting a prime membership because it really bugged me that I couldn't stream amazon instant video onto an android tablet. I don't want to go out and buy a kindle or ipad just to watch it. I finally decided to get prime, and found very helpful people on the internet.  Here is the simple solution - get the Dolphin browser app. Dolphin allows you to watch flash. However, amazon now uses silverlight instead of flash, but there is a work around for that too. You no longer have to go online and download special packages, it's all updated. (When I did my research, people said I had to side load the Dolphin jetpack, but I didn't, it must be updated now). All I did was this:

Install the dolphin browser app in the playstore.

If you try to play amazon video, it will ask you to install silverlight. It won't play, because you need to use flash.

So then, when you are in the dolphin browser, go to the amazon page, then go to the amazon instant video page or amazon prime page. (You can do this part from any browser and from any computer)

There is a link at the top more towards the right, that says "settings." Click that, then scroll down to where it says Web Player Preferences. It will probably be checked on Silverlight.  Change it to use "flash" instead of "silverlight." Then you are good to go! I don't know if this affects playback on your other devices, but now you can watch your prime content on your tablet. Hope this helps.

My Kindle Fire recently became a paperweight when its touch-screen became unusable. I really wanted to replace it with an iPad Mini, but was discouraged by the price and the fact that the WiFi version didn't have GPS. I wanted a new Kindle reader that doubled as a moving-map GPS. The Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 does all that for not much more than the cost of a Kindle Fire HD.

Pros:
  GPS!
  Great fit and finish
  Bright, clear screen
  Front and back cameras
  Small and light
  SD slot for up to 32GB expansion, if you can use it
  Includes charger
  Cheap accessories

Cons:

  Only 8GB internal storage
  Flaky WiFi
  KitKat problems

Review:

  I have a drawer full of crummy Android tablets. Anything priced less than $100 is a bad bet. Some tablets, like the Viewsonic G-Tablet, are good hardware but lack any decent software support. Others just break in a short time. I was tired of playing Android Roulette.

  The first thing that impresses you with the Tab 4 is its build quality,light weight and thinness. I found the screen to be somewhat better than the Kindle Fire HD: it's whiter and brighter, easier to read, even in sunlight. I bought an i-Blason cover for $8, much cheaper than the typical Kindle cover at $40 and just as serviceable. The cover includes a pen/stylus, which can help when touching small buttons.

  There are other bonuses, including front and rear-facing cameras. The Tab 4 has been criticized for its low-res 3MP rear camera, but it's adequate for many uses. I added a 32GB SD card. This is essential when using a large content apps like the moving-map Sygic app, which BTW is awesome.

  My first impression of Android tablets was not good; many just looked and behaved like overgrown phones. The Samsung version of Android, while also used in its Galaxy phones, seems more appropriate to tablet use, similar to iOS implementation on Apple products. I was satisfied by the customized Android OS on the Kindle Fire, but now prefer the relative freedom and ease of use of the Tab 4, plus the availability of both the Samsung Galaxy Store as well as Google Play.

  I think the Tab 4 is a very good piece of hardware, but I docked it a star owing to issues related to its KitKat OS.

  It has problems when using external SD cards under KitKat. Google has made external storage much more restricted and apps must be able to move their files into the external cards' /Android/data folder. While there is a button under Settings that says "move to sd card" it really moves it to an emulated sdcard in device memory. Fortunately, Sygic can deal with this problem and will move its files to external storage if you follow the steps on their website. I tried similar tricks to move Kindle files but it still reverts to emulated storage. I hope Amazon issues an update that will address this problem. Meanwhile, you only have 3.5GB available unless the app is "KitKat aware". This is a serious limitation. I've tried many apps, e.g. music players, and they won't show music files if they are in external storage. The only way I can consistently copy files into external storage is to hook up the Tab 4 to my PC and use Windows Explorer to do it. The only surefire way to fix this involves "rooting" the device or using adb, which I don't want to mess with at this time.

  It often drops WiFi connections. Since I didn't buy the Tab 4 for heavy online use it is an annoyance, but not a major one. Turning off all the auto and constant network scanning options (Settings/Wi-Fi/Advanced) seems to help. When all else fails, do a full shut-down and restart; once it starts to drop its connections it just gets worse.

  While I wish I'd bought the 8" version and the WiFi can be a pain, the Galaxy Tab 4 is the best tablet I've used so far, especially for a price not much higher than the Kindle Fire HD. I wanted to give it 5 stars, but the KitKat issues are too irksome. Until KitKat gets fixed I would be wary of assuming newer is better. At the same time I really like using it as a Kindle reader and it's outstanding as a GPS device. If you can tolerate the KitKat "features" it is a great value.

I've been browsing around for a smaller tablet since owning (and eventually giving away) the coveted (or cursed) Asus Transformer Prime. I wanted something smaller, but good enough for movies, books, and overall media consumption. I also wanted something that complemented by Galaxy S3 phone. The Tab 4 7 inch hits on all those points very well.

For starters, the build quality of the device is superb. The silver lining to the plastic casing adds enough class for any American (because we love our chrome) and acts as a metaphor to Samsung's pledge to near Apple-like quality. I chose the candy white model and it looks great. The plastic doesn't feel cheap and it has a nice weight to it. It seems it's internals are tightly packed resulting in a very thin profile. The thin bezel on the sides really help carry its slim style forward as well. I noticed other tablets like the MeMo 7 inch and LG G Pad 7 inch, which have thicker bezels, and it detracted from the overall experience of the tablet.

The 7 inch screen is glorious. The colors are washed (grayed) very slightly, but I didn't notice until I read an Engadget review about it. The brightness of the tablet exceeded many of the others in its class. Its really bright and it helps when viewing in direct sunlight.

The downside to the tablet is the performance, but I never felt like it left me hanging for too long. Applications might take a bit-longer to open and the Touchwiz UI may not be as smooth as it's higher-end pro series kin. None the less, again, I never felt impatient. A better way to put it is that the performance was very consistent -- slower than other higher-spec tablets but consistent, and I find that meeting expectations with regards to performance is better than having a high-spec tablet that has unexpected slowdowns (in the case for the Asus Tegra tablets). The Tab 4 7 inch is not using the Snapdragon S400 chipset as originally suggested by several review sites. It's using something else. Also, don't expect to play games very well; even Angry birds (when zoomed out) had some noticeable lag when panning across the map. That said, Minecraft played very well with some of the graphics settings turned down.

The tablet also has 1.5GB of memory, which is 500MB more than most in its class. But Samsung is going to need that extra 500MB for its hefty Touchwiz UI and bloat-apps. However, samsung allows you to "turn off" apps, many of which come preinstalled.

All-in-all this is a fantastic tablet. I've went back and forth between several other 7 inch tablets (Asus MeMo, LG G Pad, Nexus 7), and its performance and specs are very yesteryear. However, regardless of those downsides, there's some about it that I just love that goes beyond it's performance. When taken as a whole, I love the tablet and I can't put my finger on it as to why. I don't know if its the way that Samsung designed it with its sleek design or it's TouchWiz UI, but the entire package is fantastic. I've went back to the store maybe 2-3 times to try the other tablets. Yeah, they performed a little better, but that Samsung tablet caught my eye and I never regretted buying it.

It's on the shelf for $170 when I bought it, and it's worth every penny of it, I just wish they put a better chip on the inside.

I also tried a few other pads and here is some of the comparisons (in similar price points)
Samsung Galaxy tab 4 7.0
Memo pad 8 (ME181C-A1)
Memo Pad 7 (ME176CX-A1)

Battery:  All about the same
Samsung Galaxy tab 4 - About 6 hours, full brightness and netflix over wifi before warning comes up
Memo pad 8 (ME181C-A1) - About 6 hours, full brightness and netflix over wifi before warning comes up
Memo Pad 7 (ME176CX-A1) - Slightly longer, ~ 6 hours, full brightness (brightness is lower, so...) and netflix over wifi before warning comes up

Screen:
Resolution: same
Samsung Galaxy tab 4 - Same
Memo pad 8 (ME181C-A1) - Same
Memo Pad 7 (ME176CX-A1) - Same

Brightness/Color: Winner: Samsung *not by much
Samsung Galaxy tab 4 - Best in brightness and color, at max brightness best i have seen with good colors
Memo pad 8 (ME181C-A1) - My eyes couldn't tell too much difference in brightness to Samsung at first, colors by themselves look great, compared to Samsung same at low brightness (somewhat washed out at full brightness, but if not comparing is still good.)
Memo Pad 7 (ME176CX-A1)- Lowest brightness (not an issue for me unless in full sunlight and then the Samsung still wasn't readable)

Sound: No clear winner * with caveat (all have speaker on back, and all have the headphone noise level just a little bit too low)
Samsung Galaxy tab 4 - maybe slightly better without headphones, no comparable difference  for no audiophile using headphones
Memo pad 8 (ME181C-A1) - Comparable to the Samsung, both with and without headphones
Memo Pad 7 (ME176CX-A1)- The one I got had some weird feedback/ noise issue, I went to test out others in a store and didn't exhibit the issue (returning to get a new one), slightly heavier on base

Performance/Lag/stuttering:  Tie on Memo Pads, Samsung FAILED for me on more than a few games.
Samsung Galaxy tab 4 - Bad lag and stuttering to the point that it was unplayable on some games
Memo pad 8 (ME181C-A1) - Had learned my lesson on the Memo 7 and saw no issues
Memo Pad 7 (ME176CX-A1)- Originally had some lag and then noticed it was installing ALL of my apps in the background, once I waited for that to happen the lags were gone (also turned off the auto update on apps).

Camera: Memo Pad 8
Samsung Galaxy tab 4 7.0 -> decent camera,
Memo pad 8 (ME181C-A1) - Good camera, The rapid shoot option is really cool for action shots; however, needs LIGHT
Memo Pad 7 (ME176CX-A1)- Worst camera, not a show stopper for me as I don't intend to use the camera often on a tablet

Other:
Samsung Galaxy tab 4 7.0 -> the IR blaster is a cool idea; however, have it on my samsung phone and note 10 and simply don't use it, as stated earlier kids mode is nice
Memo pad 8 (ME181C-A1) - Rapid camera mode, power buttons are weird locations:  harder to accidentally turn off table, harder to intentionally turn off tablet
Memo Pad 7 (ME176CX-A1)- power buttons are weird locations:  harder to accidentally turn off table, harder to intentionally turn off tablet

Apps:
Samsung Galaxy tab 4 7.0 -> I usually hate the bloatware, both have them, The kids account option is nice; however, can get similar options through google play, textured back
Memo pad 8 (ME181C-A1) - Bloatware similar (different) than samsung, no kids account option, but can get something similar through Google play, textured back
Memo Pad 7 (ME176CX-A1)- Bloatware similar (different) than samsung, no kids account option, but can get something similar through Google play, smooth back

Price: Memo Pad 7
Samsung Galaxy tab 4 7.0 -> More expansive for a the 7, by $20-40 or more with recent Amazon sale  on Asus Memos
Memo pad 8 (ME181C-A1) - Only 10 more to get a 8 inch tablet with recent Amazon sale
Memo Pad 7 (ME176CX-A1)- Best price by far saves 20-40, get a case and some other accessories

For me the Memo Pads are the better option now trying to decide between the 7 and the 8 :)

I have had this for one month.  I will be returning it and using a Nexus 7 (Asus; 2013 model).  The deal breaker has been the camera, though I have a couple other gripes.  I previously had an HTC flyer which had a 5mp camera and took great shots.  When it died I bought this Galaxy Tab 4.  The Tab has only a 3mp camera and pictures turn out blurry, especially in low light.  I took my Tab to the store and did side-by-side photo comparisons with a Nexus 7 (Asus) and there was a huge difference in brightness, color, and ability to frame the shot.  For some reason, the Tab's camera seems to be slightly zoomed in.  For example, it is hard to take a picture of person sitting across small table as they are too zoomed in.

In summary, these were the reasons I liked Nexus 7 better:
1. Better camera (5mp v 3mp)
2. MUCH brighter white screen.  Tab seems almost grey at it's brightest setting.
3. Wifi disconnect issues; the Tab has to be reconnected to my home Wifi several times per day.  I've read it's a Kitkat problem, but I am NOT having this problem any more on the Nexus. Of note, however, the Nexus updated itself to Kitkat 4.4.4 so maybe it is fixed.  Interestingly, the Samsung says it's "up to date" at 4.4.2.
4. The Nexus just seems to be faster.  Facebook and everything else open faster.

The Nexus is slightly longer (vertically) than the Tab.  Originally I was concerned as I wanted my tablet to fit easily in my purse.  The difference in size may actually be an advantage, as there is more room to "hold" the Nexus v the Tab.

If there is a disadvantage to the Nexus, it is that it does not have expandable memory (i.e. slot for mini sd card).  So if you want 32G and don't want to pay for a more expensive Nexus, this Tab would probably be the cheaper route.

Hope this is helpful to anyone trying to decide between the two.

I received the Galaxy Tab 4 for a Birthday present and spent a week putting it through the trials of normal tablet uses, and after I week I'm a little disappointed.

First of I just want to say I am impressed with the interface Samsung developed for the galaxy brand of devices, but the amount of preinstalled apps (Crap-ware) that bog down the device is a little annoying. Which brings me to performance, the device was very laggy with all the stuff that was competing for memory, which is only 1.5gb. Just normal navigation is annoying, when compared to even a 3 year old iPad. When browsing the web, the screen sometimes freezes for a few seconds, then rushes to catch up be performing all those inputs you mashed trying to get the system to respond.

Also the wifi, it would cut out for no reason, requiring me to turn off the wifi then turn it back on to get it to work again, and no its not my router.

Overall I would not recommend the Galaxy Tab 4, anybody who needs a 7in tablet so spring for a older model Kindle Fire HD or spend the extra money to get a Nexus 7 or Kindle Fire HDX.

A couple of my relatives have both the iPad and the iPad Mini, but when I tried both of them myself, nothing compares to the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4. The iPad Mini is a little bigger than this and a little lighter, but from what I experienced, the Samsung is better and it saved me $200-400.

The reading is great and I mostly download my books straight from Google Play Books and the Amazon Kindle Store. The Wattpad app (YouTube for E-books) is an awesome app for downloading free books written by teens and tranditional/self-published authors. The keyboard is great when it comes to commenting on the works and also typing my own stories.

The battery lasts much longer, too. I had mine at 100% charged and it lasted for about twelve hours of playing time (with the brightness turned to low). I have the Netflix app and I can watch the videos perfectly. It's crystal clear.

Listening to music is much more clear and easier when you put some ear buds on. The speaker is on the back of the device.

Overall, the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 is a perfection! You should buy it!

I recognize that I am in an era in which 'everyone' has a smart phone.  I also want to say that prior to retirement, I spent 15 years in the I.T. dept. of a large company.  My wife and I looked at smart phones, and particularly, at prices of bundled family plans with smart phones.  We were very disappointed at how much more money we were going to have to pay to upgrade from a flip phones bundle to a smart phone bundle.  We were put off by having to buy internet packages twice a month - one for home and one for phones (with a capped limit).  I also questioned my friends, and discovered that all of them rarely use their phone internet, but always try to wait until they get to a free wi-fi zone to surf.  For these reasons, we went with a tablet for travel purposes - a one time purchase - with no monthly bill.  This is not a review to say that Samsung has the best one.  But, it had all the features we needed at a price I was comfortable with.  We love this tab.

I purchased last year a Galaxy Note 8 for $399.99, since then Samsung has released the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 7.0, Galaxy Tab 3 8.0, Galaxy Tab 4 7.0, Galaxy Tab 4 8.0, Galaxy Tab Pro 8.4 and now the Galaxy Tab S 8.4. Do you know how much the Galaxy Note 8 is worth now? Less than $149.99, in just about a year. Do you know how much the iPad mini (1st generation) is worth now after more than a year? $270. That's what I mean. Is not worth buying these Samsung tablets. If you are new to the market and want to try I would highly recommend you to buy these tablets after 6 months they are released so you get a good deal (because by that time samsung would have released 3 new models) or I would recommend buying it but sell it before is too late (what I did with the Note 8).

Pros
It's easy to use.
It's durable. See the knife and hammer test on You Tube.
It has decent processor speed. I'm not a heavy app gamer. So I'm happy with it.
Honestly turning an ebook page for 4 secs is pretty damn fast. If it took 3 minutes then I would understand why people gripe about the processor speed.
The touch screen is quite responsive even with a screen protector on.
WiFi is good. My kitchen is on the first floor at the back. My router is in my room on the 2nd floor witch is at the front. From that distance this device can pick up the signal. It can also pick up signals from my neighbors houses. The only time i notice any lag is if a page or video is poorly coded.
Sound is good but even better with head phones.
The battery life is good but you can squeeze more juice out if you tone down the screen brightness. And adjust the other settings.
It has a micro SD slot. Totally trumps the iPad there.
It's very light weight. Thin too.
Has a very clean UI. Not crowded and confusing.
The device and charger do not heat up.
It syncs very well with my online accounts.
GPS on this tablet is fairly accurate. I live in St. Louis and GPS doesn't always work well due to street renames, buildings sitting behind another one and such.
Controls are responsive, it will only take a feather light touch.
I can't speak about Bluetooth connection and the IR blaster because I have no comparable devices to test them  with. Edit
July 2,2014 lol I forgot my cell has blue tooth capabilities. This tab was able to connect to my Samsung Galaxy Y (Hello Kitty edition).

Cons. The cameras could have been better. Only 3 mega pixels for the back and 1 for the front. Come on Samsung at least give us 5 mega pixels! Colors look a bit saturated even in bight light. It's just OK enough to use the outer camera as a QR scanner just don't expect much.

I like the speed. I had an issue watching videos but adobe air and a flash browser solved that issue..
I purchased one for my ex-mother-in-law. It was a bargain and just large enough.

This is a decent, low cost, no frills tablet.  The screen isn't the sharpest, it is not the lightest or thinnest, the processor isn't the latest model, the camera isn't the best, but it is only $200 so it is hard to complain.

I thank Samsung for including an SD card slot, not having one is a deal breaker for me.  Some companies would rather not include one and then charge you an extra $100 for 16 additional GB's of storage -- that is basically a slap in the face when you can get 64GB sd cards for less than $50.

The one thing this tablet is missing is an LED notification light!  Not having one is a huge disappointment.  On most android phones you get a small LED that will flash a certain color when you have notifications, but on this tablet I constantly have to pick it up and turn it on to see if I missed any notifications when I stepped away from my desk.

Very disappointed with this tablet and Samsung. I purchased this two years ago and have never received a firmware update. I have the wifi version and it has Android 4.4.2 which isn't supported by more and more apps. Additionally, this version of Android makes it impossible to fully utilize the nice new SD card I bought for it. It's also loaded with bloatware so I have to manually free up space on it. It's basically been an ebook reader.

I regret this purchase and do not recommend this tablet.
